questions.text: The following sign is seen in injury of __________
questions.solution:
The given image shows ape/simian thumb deformity, which is seen in median nerve injury.

Ape/Simian thumb deformity is thenar atrophy, thumb, in lateral rotation and adduction (intact adductor pollicis with paralyzed thenar muscles).

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with subcutaneous mycosis. Which of the following infections is an example of this?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis is an example of a subcutaneous mycosis. The other three conditions present as systemic mycosis.

Subcutaneous mycoses are usually caused by traumatic inoculation of the causative fungus in skin. Fungi causing such subcutaneous mycoses are either normally present in the soil or are pathogens of plant. These include:

  • Mycotic mycetoma
  • Chromomycosis
  • Sporotrichosis
  • Rhinosporidiosis
  • Subcutaneous phycomycosis

Sporotrichosis is caused by a dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. It usually follows minor trauma like thorn prick in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc. and is more common in Himalayan hilly areas (Himachal Pradesh).

Nodules develop first at the site of the lesion and later undergo necrosis and ulceration. This is called cutaneous sporotrichosis. There is spread along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, supportive, and indurated. This is called lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis which is characterised by presence of cord like, hardened lymphatics.

Diagnosis:

  • On histopathology, asteroid bodies are seen with rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like bodies 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell
  • Culture – Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia. S.schenckii is a dimorphic fungus occurring in the yeast phase (in tissues and in cultures) at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase (in nature and cultures) at 25°C.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide oral or topical
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole
  • Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B

The below image shows nodules along the lymphatics in sporotrichosis

 

Asteroid bodies seen in sporotrichosis are shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyzes the final step in the synthesis of heme?
questions.solution:
Ferrochelatase catalyses the incorporation of ferrous iron into protoporphyrin III, which is the final step in heme synthesis. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to erythropoietic protoporphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following ovarian tumours is identical to testicular seminoma?
questions.solution:
Dysgerminoma is identical to testicular seminoma.

Few similarities between seminoma and dysgerminoma:

  • Histology:
    • large vesicular cells having a clear cytoplasm
    • well-defined cell boundaries
    • centrally placed regular nuclei
  • Express OCT3/4 and NANOG
  • Activating mutations in the KIT gene

questions.text: RET gene is located on:
questions.solution:
RET gene is a proto-oncogene located on chromosome 10q11.

RET gene:

  • Reciprocal translocation with chromosome 17: RET/PTC (RET/papillary thyroid carcinoma)- present in papillary thyroid cancers.
  • Loss-of-function mutations: intestinal aganglionosis and Hirschsprung disease.
  • Gain of function mutations: MEN 2A and MEN 2B.

MEN-2 patients carrying germline RET mutations are offered prophylactic thyroidectomy to prevent the development of medullary carcinomas.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about exhumation:

choices.text: Family members can be present during exhumation

questions.solution:

Exhumation: legal digging out of an already buried body from the grave.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dull pain and heaviness over the right lower abdomen for two months. Imaging reveals a right-sided multiloculated cystic ovarian mass and cystic dilation of the appendix, with mural calcification. Which among the following conditions is most likely associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei?
questions.solution:
The condition most likely to be associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei among the given options is a mucinous ovarian tumor.

Pseudomyxoma peritonei refers to abundant mucoid or gelatinous material surrounded by a thin fibrous capsule in the pelvis or abdominal cavity that results from an ovarian mucinous carcinoma with ascites. 

Mucinous ovarian tumors are predominantly true epithelial tumors and are mostly undetected primary intestinal cancers of the appendix or colon. Ovarian mucinous tumors associated with pseudomyxoma peritonei are usually metastatic tumors.

Well-differentiated type of mucinous tumors resembles those that originate from the intestine or endocervix. These are mucin-secreting adenocarcinomas. Advanced mucinous ovarian tumors have the worst prognosis. 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors

questions.text: Which of the following disorders cause dwarfism due to growth hormone receptor mutation?
questions.solution:
Laron-type dwarfism, also known as GH-insensitivity syndrome, is characterized by GH-Receptor anomalies.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder and the primary clinical symptom associated with this condition is short stature. When left untreated, adult males with Laron syndrome typically reach a maximum height of about 4.5 feet and adult females may be just over 4 feet tall.

The only specific treatment available for this condition is subcutaneous injections of insulin-like growth factor 1 (a growth-promoting hormone), often called IGF-1.

Other options:

  • Achondroplasia is the most common cause of dwarfism and is due to a mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor 3.
  • Diastrophic dysplasia is an autosomal recessive disorder due to dysplasia which affects cartilage and bone development.
  • Noonan syndrome also causes dwarfism and is due to Ras/mitogen-activated protein kinase mutations.

questions.text: A particular sample of urine tests positive for Benedict’s test, tests negative with the glucose oxidase test, and gives a blue color on performing Bial’s test. Identify the substance responsible for the findings:
questions.solution:
The findings suggest excretion of a reducing pentose in urine, and hence, xylulose is the answer.

A positive Benedict’s test indicates that a reducing sugar is excreted in urine. Blue color on the Bial’s test indicates that the reducing sugar is a pentose.

Xylulose is excreted in essential pentosuria due to the deficiency of xylulose reductase enzyme. The condition is benign and does not need treatment. The only clinical relevance of this condition is that the urine tests positive for reducing sugars and the condition may be mistaken for diabetes mellitus.

Note: With hexose sugars, a red, green or brown color is obtained in the Bial’s test.

questions.text: Closure of the inner aspect of the cranial sutures occurs:

choices.text: 5-10 years after closure of outer aspect
5-10 years earlier than closure of outer aspect
Earlier in females as compared to males
Less uniformly as compared to outer aspect

questions.solution:
Cranial sutures:

  • Closure of the cranial sutures begins on the inner aspect by 5–10 years earlier than on the outer aspect.
  • Fusion of sutures occurs comparatively early in males.
  • Endocranial sutural closure is more uniform and more complete than ectocranial suture.

Accurate estimation of age cannot be done on the basis of sutural closure of skull.

questions.text: Which of the following mastectomy procedures involves only retraction of pectoralis minor, dissection of level III lymph nodes, and preservation of pectoralis major?
questions.solution:
In Auchincloss procedure, the pectoralis minor is only retracted and not removed.

Patey and Dyson’s technique included removal of the breast and axillary lymph nodes(Level I to III) and removal of pectoralis minor, with preservation of the pectoralis major.

In Scanlon’s procedure, the pectoralis minor muscle is divided but not removed.

In Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple areola complex + skin + Level I + II + III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor is removed.

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: How many carbon atoms are added to the acyl chain for each malonyl CoA in fatty acid biosynthesis?
questions.solution:
Each molecule of malonyl CoA contributes 2 carbon atoms to the acyl chain in fatty acid biosynthesis.

Initially, malonyl CoA with its three carbon atoms is attached to the –SH group of the acyl carrier protein (ACP). During attachment of the acyl chain to this malonyl CoA molecule, one carbon atom is lost as CO2. Hence, two carbon atoms are added for every molecule of malonyl CoA.

Related Pearl: Biosynthesis of Fatty acids

questions.text: Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing:
questions.solution:
Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (MALToma).

Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by chronic and persistent inflammation of the salivary glands. Initially, there is a polyclonal immune reaction, but additional mutations acquired over time may lead to the development of B-cells which can multiply even in the absence of growth signals. This is the point at which marginal zone lymphoma develops. Recent studies have shown that patients with Sjögren's syndrome are also at an increased risk for multiple myeloma.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein exocrine glands such as lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can occur in isolation or secondary to other systemic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, limited systemic sclerosis, and SLE. 

The patients usually present with drying of the mouth, difficulty in swallowing, and parotid gland enlargement. Ocular involvement may present as a gritty feeling beneath the eyelids. The workup includes the Schirmer test to determine the extent of tear production in the eyes, salivary flow tests, and serum investigations to detect specific antibodies, like anti-Ro and anti-La.  The presence of CD4+ cells on the labial biopsy confirms Sjögren's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.solution: Mexiletine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is a lignocaine analog that does not have significant first-pass metabolism.

questions.text: Presence of which of the following antibody is used as a criterion in the diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.solution:
Anti-cardiolipin antibody titer is used as a criterion in the diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome.

The diagnostic criteria for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome are as follows:

Clinical criteria:

  • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before 10 weeks
  • One or more deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond 10 weeks
  • Severe pre-eclampsia necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

Laboratory criteria:

  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant
  • Presence of anti-cardiolipin antibodies
  • Presence of anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies

At least one clinical and one laboratory criterion has to be present for a diagnosis to be made.

questions.text: Donovan bodies seen on biopsy is a characteristic feature of:
questions.solution:
Donovan bodies seen on the biopsy is characteristic of granuloma inguinale. 

Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes".

The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining, which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Donovan bodies appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells.

The given image shows Intracellular Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears:

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman has sustained a gunshot wound to her mid-abdomen. After examining the patient's angiogram, a trauma surgeon locates the source of bleeding from pairs of veins that typically terminate in the same vein. Which of the following veins are damaged?
questions.solution:
The right and left hepatic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

Other options:

  • The right gastroepiploic vein drains into the superior mesenteric vein, but the left one drains into the splenic vein.
  • The right gonadal and suprarenal veins drain into the inferior vena cava, whereas the left ones drain into the left renal vein.
  • The right colic vein ends in the superior mesenteric veins, but the left one terminates in the inferior mesenteric vein.

questions.text: Cheese washer’s lung is caused by?
questions.solution:
Penicillium casei causes a rare extrinsic allergic alveolitis (EAA) found in a rural environment called cheese washer's lung. It is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Other molds such as Aspergillus clavatus, Circinomucor circilloïdes, Fusarium as well, can be detected in the patient's serum.

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotype is involved in the pathogenesis of Guillian-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
IgG isotype of autoantibody is involved in the pathogenesis of GBS.

IgM isotype autoantibodies are known to play a role in some types of chronic immune neuropathies.

questions.text: Revascularization can restore the contractile function of:
questions.solution:
Revascularization can restore the contractile function of hibernating myocardium.

Hibernating myocardium is defined as myocardial tissue with abnormal but maintained cellular function secondary to chronic ischemia, and is believed to recover after revascularization leading to the notion that CABG can be used in patients in heart failure with viable myocardium.

  • Other options:

Stunned myocardium is a transient post-ischemic dysfunction seen in myocardial tissue salvaged after an ischemic episode.

  • Hibernating myocardium is ischemic, viable myocardium.

questions.text: Cortical bone graft can be taken from:
questions.solution:
Cortical bone graft can be harvested from:

  • Iliac crest
  • Any long bone

Compact/cortical bone has dense appearance. It is made up of haversian systems- central canals enclosed by concentric lamellae of bone. It is found in areas where support is required:

  • Outer walls of all bones, especially the shafts of long bones
  • Subchondral plates supporting articular cartilage

Cancellous/trabecular bone has honeycomb appearance. It is made of flattened trabecular sheets that are interconnected. It is found in the interior meshwork of all bones. It is well developed in:

  • Ends of the tubular bones
  • Vertebral bodies

Cancellous bone graft can be taken from:

  • Thicker portions of the ilium
  • Greater trochanter
  • Proximal metaphysis of the tibia
  • Lower radius
  • Olecranon
  • Excised femoral head

Related Pearl: Bone grafts and substitutes

  • Greater trochanter

questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient posted for emergency appendicectomy, the anesthetist grades him as Mallampatti class III and suspects a difficult airway. The device given in the image below can be used in this patient. The disadvantage of this device compared to an endotracheal intubation is:

choices.text: Risk of aspiration of gastric contents

questions.solution:
The given image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) which is indicated in cases with difficult airways. The disadvantage of LMA is that it increases the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

LMA is used for airway management as a temporary, life-saving measure in patients with difficult ventilation. Difficult ventilation can be either due to difficult airways, unavailability, or difficulty in mask ventilation and intubation.

Advantages of LMA:

  • Less invasive as compared to tracheal tubes.
  • Lesser bronchospasm as compared to tracheal tubes 
  • It partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions.
  • Useful in difficult intubations
  • Less trauma to teeth and pharynx
  • Muscle relaxation is not required
  • Neck mobility is not required 

Disadvantages:

  • does not protect from gastric regurgitation
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of a gas leak and pollution

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O. 


 

Related Pearl: Different sizes of the laryngeal mask airway

Mask size Patient Size  Weight (kg) Cuff Volume (mL)
1 Infant <5 2-4
1.5 Infant 5-10 upto 7
2 Child 10-20 upto 10
2.5 Child 20-30 upto 14
3 Small Adult 30-50 upto 20
4 Normal adult(women) 50-70 upto 30 
5 Normal adult >70 30-40
6 Adults >100 50

questions.text: What is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis called?
questions.solution:
The shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis is called the obstetrical conjugate.

It is clinically important because the fetal head has to pass through this diameter to descend further downwards. It cannot be measured directly. Instead, it is calculated by subtracting 1.5 to 2 cm from the diagonal conjugate. Normally, it measures 10 cm or more.

Other options:

The anatomical or the true conjugate extends from the uppermost margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory.

The diagonal conjugate is measured clinically as the distance between the lowest margin of the symphysis pubis to the sacral promontory and is about 1.5-2 cm greater than the obstetrical conjugate.

Description: Antero-posterior diameters at the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: Which among the following effects is unlikely to occur during treatment with imipramine?
questions.solution:
Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and nor-adrenaline. In addition, it possesses anticholinergic and α blocking properties.

Adverse effects of imipramine include:

  • Sedation
  • Pupillary dilatation
  • Urinary retention
  • Increased risk of seizures to due lowering of seizure threshold

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits glycogenolysis in the muscle?
questions.solution:
Glucose-6-phosphate and ATP inhibit glycogenolysis in the muscle.

Other options:

  • 5’ AMP allosterically activates muscle phosphorylase even when it is in the inactivated/dephosphorylated state.
  • Cytosolic calcium activates muscle phosphorylase kinase which in turn activates muscle phosphorylase.
  • Muscle phosphorylase is active in the phosphorylated state.

Note: Liver phosphorylase differs from the muscle isoenzyme in that it doesn’t bind 5’ AMP and is also inactivated by free glucose.

questions.text: A cervical dilation of 5 cm after two hours of plotting on the WHO simplified partograph falls under what zone?
questions.solution:
A cervical dilation of 5 cm after two hours of recording on a WHO simplified partograph falls under the amber zone. The cervical dilation is plotted from 4 centimetres of dilation and since the rate of dilation is less than 1 cm/hr, the alert line is crossed.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: What does the term folate trap refer to?
questions.solution:
The term folate trap refers to accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate with deficiency of tetrahydrofolate. It is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency.

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, vitamin B12 deficiency leads to folate deficiency.

Since vitamin B12 is also linked to regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, there is hyperhomocysteinemia as well. It increases the risk of atherosclerosis, hypertension and thrombosis.

questions.text: According to the WHO, a child is severely malnourished if________
questions.solution:
A child is severely malnourished if weight/height is less than -3SD, according to WHO.

Note: Weight-for-age is not a parameter for the WHO classification of malnutrition. It has limited clinical significance as it does not differentiate between wasting and stunting.

WHO classification of malnutrition:

Parameter  Moderate malnutrition Severe malnutrition
Symmetrical edema no yes
weight/height (wasting) -2 to -3 SD(70 to 79% of expected) < -3 SD (<70%)
Height/age (stunting) -2 to -3 SD(85 to 89%) < -3 SD (<85%)

questions.text: According to the FIGO classification, tumor of the ovary involving the fallopian tube but not extending to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissue is classified under what stage?
questions.solution:
Ovarian tumor involving the fallopian tube comes under stage IIA according to the FIGO classification.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus includes:
questions.solution:
The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (Adam’s/Hakim’s triad):

  • Dementia
  • Ataxia (gait disturbance) or apractic
  • Urinary incontinence

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. Timely diagnosis and prompt intervention can lead to the reversal of symptoms in NPH.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Hakim-Adams syndrome):

  • It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.
  • Caused by conditions producing scarring of basilar meninges
  • Communicating hydrocephalus is seen
  • Adam’s / Hakim’s triad (as mentioned above)
  • Papilloedema is not seen.
  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures may appear propped open (so-called “boxcarring”), which can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy.
  • Treatment-  Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure

questions.text: A 70-year-old obese male presents with bilateral knee pain worsening on exertion. On examination, a palpable nodule was found in the 2nd DIP joint in his right hand as shown below. The patient has no other complaints. What is the appropriate pharmacological method to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical scenario presented the most probable diagnosis is osteoarthritis. The nodules palpable in the DIP are Heberden’s nodes. NSAIDs (like ibuprofen) followed by regular follow-up is the most appropriate way of managing the patient among the options provided.

Other options:

  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used in the treatment of gouty arthritis as a hypouricemic agent.
  • Secukinumab is an anti-IL-17A monoclonal antibody used for the management of psoriatic arthritis.
  • Intra-articular steroids are provided if the patient does not respond to Acetaminophen/NSAIDs, it is not the first-line treatment for osteoarthritis. Furthermore, its efficacy in the treatment of OA is controversial. Thus, the best option is NSAIDs.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with acantholysis resulting due to damage to keratinocytes causing loss of desmosomes?
questions.solution:
Acantholysis resulting due to damage to keratinocytes causing loss of desmosomes is secondary acantholysis. This is seen in bullous impetigo.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

  • Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholuysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:
    • Pemphigus and its variants
    • Acantholytic dermatosis
    • Darier's disease
    • Hailey Hailey disease
    • Warty dyskeratoma
  • Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:
    • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles)
    • Bullous impetigo
    • Solar keratoses
    • Squamous cell carcinoma - some forms like adenoid

The image below shows acantholysis and dyskeratosis as seen in Darier's disease.

questions.text: Minimum number of people required for the following maneuver in a trauma patient according to ATLS is:
questions.solution:
The image shows the log rolling procedure in a trauma patient. At least four people are needed for logrolling a patient to remove a spine board and/or examine the back.

  • One person stands at the patient’s head to control the head and C-Spine and two are along the patient’s sides to control the body and extremities.
  • As the patient is rolled, three people maintain alignment of the spine.
  • Fourth person removes the board and examines the back.
  • Once the board is removed, three people return the patient to the supine position while maintaining alignment of the spine.

Recent update: The 10th edition of ATLS recommends at least 4 people for safe maneuver of log roll in patients suffering from trauma.

  • First person is assigned to restrict motion of the head and neck.
  • Second person positioned on the same side of the patient’s torso manually prevent segmental rotation, flexion, extension, lateral bending, or sagging of the chest or abdomen while transferring the patient.
  • Third person is responsible for moving the patient’s legs
  • Fourth person removes the backboard and examines the back.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is likely to be associated with this nail finding?
questions.solution:
The image depicting dorsal nail pterygium is a nail change seen in lichen planus. It is the most specific nail change in lichen planus where the fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium formation.

Other nail changes associated with lichen planus are:

  • Thinning of the nail plate: Most common nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions.
  • Pup-tent sign: Elevation of nail in the shape of a tent
  • Trachonychia: All 20 nails of hands and feet undergo dystrophy
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Longitudinal melanonychia in lichen planus of the nail bed
  • Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: Excessive ingestion of iodine in a person who is not iodine deficient causes?
questions.solution:
Excess iodine transiently inhibits thyroid iodide organification and is known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.

Other options:

  • Jod-Basedow phenomenon: Hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone production by autonomous nodules following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing substances in patients with endemic iodine deficiency.
  • Thyrotoxicosis factitia: Ingestion of excess thyroid hormone leading to thyrotoxicosis without hyperthyroidism.
  • De Quervain's thyroiditis (subacute thyroiditis, granulomatous thyroiditis or viral thyroiditis): Characterized by inflammatory infiltrate leading to initial hyperthyroid phase due to follicular destruction followed by a hypothyroid phase due to thyroid hormone depletion.

questions.text: Which of the following eye drops is used in collagen cross linking treatment for keratoconus?
questions.solution:
Riboflavin eye drops is used in collagen cross linking therapy for keratoconus. The corneal epithelium is removed and riboflavin eye drops is instilled until the cornea is saturated with riboflavin. The cornea is then exposed to UVA and covered using a soft bandage lens. Riboflavin acts as a photo sensitising agent and promotes cross linking of collagen fibres. This stabilises the corneal stroma and delays progression of the disease.

Other options:

Verteporfin is a photosensitizing dye used in photodynamic therapy.

questions.text: The parenchyma of a normal liver is most likely to survive the obstruction of:
questions.solution:
The parenchyma of a normal liver is most likely to survive the obstruction of the main hepatic artery because of these additional sources of blood supply:

  • Accessory vessels
  • Portal venous supply

Other options:

Intrahepatic portal vein radicles obstruction- results in infarct of Zahn:

  • Area of red-blue discoloration
  • No necrosis
  • Severe hepatocellular atrophy
  • Marked stasis in distended sinusoids.

Portal vein obstruction- leads to portal hypertension- abdominal pain, esophageal varices.

The obstruction of two or more major hepatic veins- causes Budd-Chiari syndrome presenting as liver enlargement, pain, and ascites. The affected hepatic parenchyma shows severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis.

Note: Hepatic artery thrombosis in a transplanted liver leads to infarction of the major ducts of the biliary tree since their blood supply is entirely arterial.

questions.text: What is the most common site of primary mucosal melanoma in the head and neck region?
questions.solution: The most common site for primary mucosal melanoma in the head and neck region is the sinonasal cavity region (more often the nasal septum and the lateral walls of the nose followed by the sinuses).

questions.text: Lymphatic drainage of prostate is into:
questions.solution:
Lymphatic vessels from the prostate drain mainly into the internal iliac, sacral, and obturator lymph nodes.

It is important to note is that lymphatic drainage of the prostate is highly variable. Many of the lymph vessels from prostate anastomose with their counterparts of several neighboring organs, for example of the urinary bladder and rectum. This can have important clinical implications, especially in cases of prostate cancer.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING
Para - aortic lymph nodes Ovaries /Testis
External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is done in a non-pregnant woman with a unicornuate uterus?
questions.solution:
Excision of rudimentary horn is done in non-pregnant women with unicornuate uterus. This is done to avoid the risk of an ectopic pregnancy in the rudimentary horn and eventual rupture.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications

  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery

  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding stage (stage 2). 

The demographic gap refers to the difference between birth rates and death rates within a population, leading to changes in population size and age structure.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: VDRL test is an example of:
questions.solution:
VDRL test for syphilis is an example of slide flocculation test.

Flocculation: When a soluble antigen combines with its antibody in the presence of electrolytes at a suitable temperature and pH, the antigen-antibody complex forms an insoluble precipitate that remains suspended as floccules. It is a type of precipitation reaction.

  • Slide flocculation test: When a drop of the antigen and the antiserum are placed on a slide and mixed by shaking, floccules appear. eg. VDRL test.
  • Tube flocculation test: Serial dilutions of the toxin/ toxoid are added to the tubes containing a fixed quantity of the antitoxin causing floccules to appear. eg. Kahn test for syphilis.

Agglutination: When a particulate antigen is mixed with its antibody in the presence of electrolytes at a suitable temperature and pH, the particles are clumped or agglutinated. It is more sensitive for the detection of antibodies.

  • Slide agglutination test: When a drop of the appropriate antiserum is added to a uniform suspension of a particulate antigen on a slide, agglutination takes place. It is used for blood grouping and cross-matching.
  • Tube agglutination test: When a fixed volume of a particulate antigen suspension is added to an equal volume of serial dilutions of an antiserum in test tubes, agglutination takes place. eg. Widal test for typhoid.

questions.text: Massive transfusion is defined as:

choices.text: > 10 units of packed RBCs within the first 24hrs
> 10 units of packed RBCs within the first 12hrs

questions.solution:
Massive transfusion is most often defined as more than 4 units of RBCs in 1 hour or > 10 units of RBCs within the first 24 hours of admission.

It is indicated in Class IV (severe) blood loss, where >40% of blood loss has occurred. Early administration of pRBCs, plasma, and platelets in a balanced ratio to minimize excessive crystalloid administration may improve patient survival.

Simultaneous efforts to rapidly control bleeding and reduce the detrimental effects of coagulopathy, hypothermia, and acidosis in these patients are extremely important.

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of transudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Superior vena cava obstruction causes transudative pleural effusion.

Transudative Pleural Effusion Exudative Pleural Effusion
Alteration in systemic factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid. Alteration in local factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid.
Causes include congestive cardiac failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, peritoneal dialysis, SVC obstruction, myxedema. Causes include neoplastic conditions like mesothelioma; infectious diseases like tuberculosis; pulmonary embolization; GI conditions like esophageal perforation, pancreatic diseases; collagen vascular diseases like SLE; asbestosis, sarcoidosis; drug-induced; hemothorax and chylothorax, etc.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

questions.text: Which among the following drugs can cause the fetal condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The above USG shows a fetus with spina bifida. Sodium valproate is associated with specific malformation of spina bifida. Pregnant women taking sodium valproate have a 1-2% risk of delivering a baby with spina bifida.

Other options:

  • Phenytoin is usually associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome, characterised by CNS anomalies, Intrauterine Growth restriction, cardiac abnormalities, cleft lip, Phalyngeal hypoplasia. Thus, the best option is sodium valproate.
  • Levetiracetam and lamotrigine are relatively safe in pregnancy and do not seem to cause neural tube defects.

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure __________
questions.solution:
The instrument given above is globe thermometer, which is used to measure mean radiant temperature—a component of corrected effective temperature.

This widely used index of thermal comfort deals with all four factors, namely air temperature, humidity, air movement or velocity, and mean radiant heat.

questions.text: In a patient with uterine dehiscence with a BP of 80/60 mmHg, what is the iv-induction agent of choice?
questions.solution:
Since the patient is hypotensive, intravenous induction agent of choice is ketamine.

Ketamine is the induction agent of choice for patients with hemodynamic compromise as it helps maintain arterial pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output due to sympathetic stimulation and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition.

Other properties of ketamine are:

  • Dissociative anesthesia with profound analgesia
  • Preserves laryngeal and pharyngeal reflex
  • Does not depress respiration
  • Bronchial dilatation

Other options:

  • Propofol and thiopentone cause hypotension following induction.
  • Etomidate although it is cardio-stable it causes a mild reduction in peripheral vascular resistance that is responsible for a slight decline in arterial blood pressure.

questions.text: The most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism is :
questions.solution:
Renal failure is the most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is caused by any condition that gives rise to chronic hypocalcemia, which in turn leads to compensatory overactivity of the parathyroid glands.

Other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Inadequate dietary intake of calcium
  • Steatorrhea
  • Vitamin D deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of celiac disease?

choices.text: Rate of malignancy is higher than normal
Villous atrophy is diagnostic of celiac disease
Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies are found

questions.solution:
Villous atrophy is not specific for celiac disease and can be present in other diseases, including viral enteritis.

The combination of histology and serology is most specific for diagnosis of celiac disease.

Celiac disease:

  • Histological features: villous atrophy, increased numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs), epithelial proliferation with crypt elongation
  • Individuals with celiac disease have a higher than normal rate of malignancy. The most common celiac disease-associated cancer is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma.
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis- itchy, blistering skin lesion, can be present in as many as 10% of patients
  • The measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase is a sensitive test for celiac disease.

questions.text: If sensitivity is 90% and specificity is 95%, calculate positive likelihood ratio:
questions.solution:
Sensitivity is 90% and Specificity is 95%.

Positive likelihood ratio: Sensitivity / 1-specificity = 18

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: The inheritance pattern shown below is:
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern shown above is mitochondrial inheritance.

Mitochondrial inheritance:

  • Caused by mutations of the mitochondrial genome.
  • Inherited exclusively from the affected mother (ovum) as an individual’s mitochondrial genome is entirely derived from the mother because sperm contain few mitochondria, which are typically shed upon fertilization.
  • Both male and female children born to an affected mother will inherit the disease.
  • These diseases include: Mitochondrial encephalopathy, Lactic acidosis and Stroke like episodes (MELAS) and other disorders tabulated below (mnemonic: KLMNOP).

questions.text: Which of the following is assessed using the test shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Rorschach inkblot test, which is a projective personality test.

10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblots are shown to the participants. The test is administered in two phases:

  • Free association phase: Participant's response to the cards is recorded
  • Inquiry phase: Participants explain why they formed the impression.

Projective tests:

These tests are based on the principle that when presented with an ambiguous stimulus, such as an inkblot, the patient's responses will reflect fundamental aspects of his or her personality. The ambiguous stimulus is a sort of screen on which the individual projects his or her own needs, thoughts, or conflicts.

Projective tests generally do not measure a particular personality type like 'type-A personality' (narrow-band measurement), but rather measure these as a 'whole' (broad-band measurement).

Commonly used projective tests are as follows:

  • Thematic apperception test
  • Rorschach's inkblot test
  • Sentence completion test
  • Draw a person test

Related Pearl: Personality tests

Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI-2)

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used objective personality test.

Useful for primary care physicians because no training is required for administration and scoring 

Evaluating the attitude of the patient toward taking the test

Objective test

Patients answer 567 true(T) or false(F) questions about themselves.

Clinical scales include depression, paranoia, schizophrenia, and hypochondriasis.

Validity scales identify trying to look ill (faking bad or malingering) or trying to look well (faking good) 

 

Rorschach Test

Uses Characteristics

The most commonly used projective personality test. 

Used to identify thought disorders and defense mechanisms

Projective test 

Patients are asked to interpret 10 bilaterally symmetrical inkblot designs (e.g., Describe what you see in this figure)

 

 

Thematic Apperception Test (TAT)

Uses Characteristics

Stories are used to evaluate unconscious emotions and conflicts

Projective test

Patients are asked to create a verbal scenario based on 20 drawings depicting ambiguous situations (e.g., Using the picture, make up a story that has a beginning, a middle, and an end)

The image given below is the first card, drawn by Christiana D. Morgan. It is a recreation of a photograph taken by Samuel Lumiere of violinist, Yehudi Menuhin, in 1928.

 

Sentence Completion Test

Uses Characteristics
Used to identify worries and problems using verbal associations

Projective test

Patients complete sentences started by the examiner

questions.text: Which of the following measures is not advocated for controlling the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis?

choices.text: The use of indoor residual sprays
Keeping pigs away from human dwellings
The use of Malathion for outdoor fogging

questions.solution:
Indoor residual sprays are not used in the vector control measures for Japanese Encephalitis, as its vectors are outdoor resters.

Japanese encephalitis is caused by group B arbovirus (Flavivirus) and transmitted by culex mosquitoes.

Prevention and control of JE:

  • Vaccination: SA-14-14-2 strain is used in India. A single dose is given followed by a single booster given at an interval of about 1 year. The children between 1 - 15 years of age are immunized.
  • Keeping pigs away from human dwellings from dusk to dawn (biting time of the vectors). Pigs act as important amplifiers of the virus.
  • Use of bed nets for personal protection.
  • Use of larvivorous fishes.
  • Using Malathion for outdoor fogging to control an outbreak.

 

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

questions.text: The posterolateral wall of the true pelvis is formed by ______
questions.solution:
The posterolateral wall of the true pelvis is formed by piriformis.

Muscles forming walls of the true pelvis:

  • Anterolateral wall: Obturator internus and the fascia over its upper, inner (pelvic), surface
  • Posterolateral wall: Piriformis
  • Floor: Levator ani and coccygeus

Bones forming the true pelvis:

  • Sacrum
  • Pubis
  • Ilium
  • Ischium

The outlet of the true pelvis is formed by the

  • Ischiopubic rami,
  • Ischial tuberosities,
  • Sacrotuberous ligaments and
  • Distal sacrum

The true pelvis starts at the level of a plane passing through sacral promontory of the sacrum, the arcuate line on the ilium, the iliopectineal line and the posterior surface of the pubic crest. This plane, or ‘inlet’, lies at an angle of between 35° and 50° from the horizontal; above this plane, the bony structures are sometimes referred to as the false pelvis.

questions.text: Which among the following statements regarding exenatide is false?

choices.text: The incidence of hypoglycemia is high in monotherapy
Treatment with exenatide is associated with pancreatitis
Should not be given in a patient with renal failure

questions.solution:
Hypoglycemia is rare in exenatide monotherapy but is higher when given along with sulphonylureas.

All the other statements are true.

Exenatide

  • Exenatide has the highest risk of acute pancreatitis.
  • It is a synthetic version of a peptide initially identified in the saliva of the Gila monster (exendin-4).
  • Because of the reliance on renal clearance, exenatide should not be given to persons with moderate-to-severe renal failure (creatinine clearance < 30 mL/min).
  • Other GLP-1 analog include: Liraglutide, albiglutide, dulaglutide, lixisenatide, semaglutide.

Drop metastases are seen in medulloblastoma.

questions.text: Identify the marked finding in a patient who underwent cataract surgery.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Soemmering’s ring. It is defined as a thick ring of after cataract or secondary cataract that persists or develops after extracapsular cataract extraction. No treatment is needed if the central posterior capsule is clear.

If the central posterior capsule is covered by a thin membrane, YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with cystitome/Zeigler’s knife is done. If the membrane is thick, surgical membranectomy is needed.

Other options:

Option A: Vossius ring – Formed after blunt trauma as a circular brown ring on the anterior lens capsule. It is caused by the contracted pupillary margin striking against the lens capsule.

Option C: Weiss or Vogt’s ring – It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment as a ring around the optic disc. This appearance is caused by the attachment of the peripapillary glial tissue to the detached vitreous cortex.

Option D: Fleischer’s ring – It refers to a brown ring formed by iron deposition around the base of the cone in keratoconus.

questions.text:
Conditions favorable for mummification include:

i. Hot weather
ii. Humid air
iii. Shallow grave
iv. Cold weather
questions.solution:
The conditions favorable for mummification include hot weather and shallow graves (option A- i, iii).

Mummification occurs in the absence of moisture and the continuous action of dry or warm air. It is a process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs due to the evaporation of water. The natural appearance of the body and general facial features are preserved.

Conditions favorable for mummification include:

  • Hot weather
  • Dry air currents
  • Shallow grave
  • Dry sandy soil

questions.text: Which of the following micro-organisms is most commonly associated with the finding shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome and the finding is most commonly associated with chlamydial infections. It is also seen frequently with gonorrheal infections.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome refers to perihepatitis seen in pelvic inflammatory disease with violin-string adhesions between the liver and the diaphragm/anterior abdominal wall. The condition is characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

questions.text: All of the following are true about nitrous oxide except:

choices.text: Pin index for nitrous oxide is 3,5

questions.solution:
Nitrous oxide has low blood solubility.

N2O, sevoflurane, and desflurane have low blood solubility.

Halothane has high blood solubility.

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: The deformity shown in the following image is characteristically seen in ___________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg), which is characteristically seen in rickets.

However, it may also be seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A middle aged woman who recently gave birth presents with uterus involution and irregular bleeding. Investigation reveals presence of trophoblastic neoplasm. What is the most common trophoblastic neoplasm after a term pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Gestational choriocarcinoma is the most common type of trophoblastic neoplasm to follow a term pregnancy or a miscarriage.

  • The tumor is composed of cells that resemble early cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast but villi are characteristically absent. It invades the uterine wall and may reach the uterine surface as dark irregular nodules. Hematological spread is the most common route of spread. It also metastasizes early and most commonly involves the lungs or the vagina. Ovarian theca lutein cysts are frequently seen along with this tumor.

Criteria for diagnosis of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is as follows:

1. Plateau of serum Beta-hCG level (± 10%) for four measurements along a period of 3 weeks. 

2. Rise of serum Beta-hCG level >1 0 percent during three weekly consecutive measurements or longer, during a period of 2 weeks

3. Serum Beta-hCG level remains detectable for 6 months or more

4. Histological criteria for choriocarcinoma

Clinical features include irregular bleeding with subinvolution of the uterus post pregnancy or a miscarriage. In severe cases, myometrial perforation occurs which causes, myometrial perforation takes place leading to intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

questions.text: An 18-year-old adolescent is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal development of secondary sexual characteristics. Her ultrasound abdomen and pelvis reveal normal ovaries but an absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics and ultrasonography showing normal ovaries and an absent uterus and upper of the vagina is suggestive of Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome. 

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or Mullerian agenesis is a condition wherein there is a congenital absence of the uterus and the vagina. The patients have a Karyotype of 46 XX, so the gonads present are ovaries. 

The patient's secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed with normal external genitalia. The ovaries are normal but have an absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. The patients usually have a blind-ended vaginal pouch. 

Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography, MRI, and laparoscopy. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity. 

Other options:

Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome, also known as testicular feminization syndrome, has a karyotype of 46XY, so the gonads present are testes. Secondary sexual characteristics like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

Option B: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. Female genital organs like the vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries are present.

Option C: Swyer syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. As there is gonadal dysgenesis in these patients, they fail to secrete testosterone and antimullerian hormone (AMH). This results in the development of female genital organs i.e. uterus and cervix are developed. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia.

questions.text: A patient with organophosphorus poisoning was given atropine. Which among the following effects of atropine is paired correctly with the receptor blocked to produce it?
questions.solution:
Atropine causes tachycardia due to the blockade of M2 receptors in the heart inhibiting the action of acetylcholine on them.

Atropine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist. Muscarinic antagonists block the effects of acetylcholine by binding to and inhibiting muscarinic receptors on effector cells in the peripheral ganglia and the CNS. Atropine is a competitive antagonist of the muscarinic receptors.

Atropine initially blocks these presynaptic M1 receptors. This increases the amount of ACh released at the SA node and causes bradycardia. Then, the progressive increase in the atropine concentration blocks the postsynaptic M2 receptors on the SA node (decreasing the ACh release) decreasing the parasympathetic tone, thereby causing tachycardia.

Other options:

Option A: Mydriasis is caused due to M3 (mainly) and M2 receptors.

Options C and D: Decreased bronchial secretions and bronchodilatation are due to M2 and M3 receptor blockade.

questions.text: Mosquirix is the world’s first malaria vaccine that has been shown to provide partial protection against malaria in young children. It is effective against _____________
questions.solution:
Mosquirix malaria vaccine RTS,S/AS01 is the world’s first malaria vaccine that has been shown to provide partial protection against malaria in young children.

The vaccine acts against Plasmodium falciparum, the most deadly malaria parasite globally and the most prevalent in Africa. The vaccine has been recommended by WHO for pilot introduction in selected areas of 3 African countries.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a start codon?
questions.solution:
The first AUG at the 5’ end generally functions as the start codon. However, the exact AUG at which transcription starts is determined by sequences surrounding the codon called Kozak consensus sequences.

Other options:

UGA, UAG, and UAA are stop codons.

UGA is translated into selenocysteine when it is accompanied by a selenocysteine insertion element in the untranslated region of the mRNA.

UAG codes for pyrrolysine in prokaryotes.

Related Pearl: Start and stop codons

Start codon: AUG - Methionine

Stop codons:

  • UGA- Selenocysteine (21st Amino acid )
  • UAG- Pyrrolysine (22nd Amino acid)
  • UAA

questions.text: Identify the finding common to carnitine deficiency, dicarboxylic aciduria, and acute fatty liver of pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Carnitine deficiency, dicarboxylic aciduria and acute fatty liver of pregnancy are all associated with impaired beta oxidation of fatty acids, which leads to nonketotic hypoglycemia. Production of ketone bodies is low due to the reduced availability of acetyl CoA, and the hypoglycemia is secondary to reduced ATP production from fatty acids.

Note: Dicarboxylic aciduria is caused by a lack of medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase. Acute fatty liver of pregnancy is caused by a lack of long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase.

questions.solution:
The microscopic examination of India-ink stained CSF is shows unicellular budding yeast with a prominent capsule- cryptococcus. Cryptococcus is known to cause meningoencephalitis in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: What is after-hyperpolarization?
questions.solution:
The fall of membrane potential below resting membrane potential is called after-hyperpolarization. This happens because of the excess efflux of potassium through the potassium channels opened during depolarization. The membrane potential returns to the resting membrane potential once these channels close.

Other options:

  • Membrane potential becoming positive is called overshoot. The ICF becomes positive compared to ECF and hence the electrical gradient for sodium is reversed.
  1. Resting state - Both channels are closed
  2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters into the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.
  3. The sodium influx causes opening of more sodium channels through positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.
  4. Sodium conductance decreases.
  5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.
  6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.
  7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: Which of the following ion has a positive Nernst equilibrium potential?
questions.solution:
Sodium ion has a positive Nernst equilibrium potential.

The Nernst equilibrium potential for an ion refers to the intracellular potential at which the chemical and electrical gradients cancel out each other. At this potential, there is no net movement of an ion between the intracellular (ICF) and extracellular fluid (ECF).

This can be illustrated with an example.

The Nernst equilibrium potential of sodium is +60 mV. This means that when the intracellular potential is +60 mV, the intracellular positive charge repelling sodium out (electrical gradient) is balanced by the higher ECF concentration of sodium (chemical gradient) which favours entry into the cell. Thus, at this potential, there is no diffusion of sodium across the cellular membrane.

Other options:

Potassium (-90 mV), Chloride (-70 mV) and protons (-12 mV) have negative Nernst potentials.

Note: Apart from sodium, calcium and magnesium also have positive Nernst potentials.

questions.text: Which among the following statements regarding TTP is false?

choices.text: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is a characteristic feature of TTP
It can be associated with deficiency in ADAMTS 13
It is associated accumulation of vWF monomers

questions.solution:
TTP is associated with an accumulation of ultra-large multimers of vWF (von Willebrand Factor) as a result of the absence, or markedly decreased the activity of the plasma protease ADAMSTS 13 (a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with a thrombospondin type 1 motif, member 13). These ultra-large multimers of vWF form clots and shear erythrocytes leading to MAHA (microangiopathic hemolytic anemia).

The characteristic pentad of TTP includes:

  • MAHA
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Neurological symptoms
  • Fever
  • Renal failure

Thrombotic microangiopathies (TMA) like TTP can also be drug-induced.

  • Ticlopidine produces TTP by inducing an autoantibody to ADAMTS13
  • Quinine appears to induce autoantibodies to granulocytes, lymphocytes, endothelial cells, and platelet glycoprotein Ibβ/IX or IIb/IIIa complexes. Quinine-associated TTP is relatively more common among women.

Note:
Upshaw-Schülman syndrome is a hereditary condition characterized by a congenital deficiency of ADAMTS13.

questions.text: Under the following scheme, Anganwadi helpers will receive a monthly incentive if they achieve __________

choices.text: Opening of Anganwadi center for at least 21 days a month
Growth monitoring of at least 60% of children under 2 years registered in an AWC
Completing at least 60% of home visits to pregnant women
Completing at least 60% of home visits to children under 2 years

questions.solution:
Anganwadi helpers (AWH) will receive a monthly incentive if they achieve the following criterion: Opening of Anganwadi center (AWC) for at least 21 days a month.

The achievement of these criteria will be determined on the basis of a picture of an open anganwadi centre with children present uploaded on ICDS-CAS. 

Other options:

All other options are fulfilling criteria for an anganwadi worker (AWW) to receive the monthly incentive, however the question asks for the incentive specifically under PM's Poshan Abhiyaan. The other options are:

  • Growth monitoring of at least 60% of children under 2 years registered at the AWC in the month.
  • Completing at least 60% of home visits to pregnant women and children up to 2 years of age as per home visit schedule for the month.

Amount of Incentive:

If the AWW achieves both the performance criteria, she will receive Rs. 500/-

If the AWH achieves the laid-out performance criteria, she will receive Rs.250/-

Other options:

questions.text: Which of the following is administered in Tolosa-Hunt syndrome?
questions.solution:
Systemic steroids are administered in Tolosa-Hunt syndrome. It is an idiopathic sterile inflammation involving the cavernous sinus with or without involvement of the optic nerve and ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. There is acute ophthalmoplegia with a gnawing or boring pain.

Steroid therapy relieves the pain as well as signs of compression within 24-48 hours. Resistant lesions are treated by radiotherapy.

questions.text: Which among the following compounds is a radiosensitizer?
questions.solution:
Gemcitabine is a radiosensitizer. Zinc oxide, amifostine and chlorhexidine are radioprotectors.

Note:

  • Radioprotectors: Radioprotectors are compounds that are designed to reduce the damage in normal tissues caused by radiation (eg., antioxidants).
  • Radiosensitizers: Radiosensitizers are agents that sensitize the tumor cells to radiation. These compounds apparently promote fixation of the free radicals produced by radiation damage at the molecular level.

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than _________.
questions.solution:
According to the Factories Act, 1948, a safety officer should be employed if the number of workers is more than 1000.

The Factories Act, 1948 states the following regarding safety and welfare measures:

  • > 1000 workers – there should be a safety officer
  • > 500 workers – there should be a welfare officer
  • > 250 workers – a canteen should be provided
  • > 30 female workers- a crèche should be provided

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Propranolol is contraindicated in a patient of angina pectoris who is already receiving:
questions.solution:
Verapamil and propranolol both decrease conduction through the AV node and their concomitant use can result in heart block.
