questions.text: Which of the following is the treatment of choice for a Bartholin’s cyst?
questions.solution:
Marsupialization is the treatment of choice for a Bartholin’s cyst.

Bartholin glands are the homologues of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. A cyst is formed when there is an obstruction in the gland or more commonly, in the duct. This causes local discomfort and dyspareunia.

Marsupialization ensures that the gland function remains intact and is a simple procedure that can be done under local anaesthesia with almost no complications. Hence it is preferred to excision of the gland.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is related to Abhiyan Indradhanush?

choices.text: Maintaining peace and harmony among employees
Ensure complete vaccination in a newborn for all vaccine preventable diseases
Change of bed sheets on all 7 days of the week

questions.solution:
Abhiyan Indradhanush in relation to Employees State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) pertains to change of bedsheets on a daily basis from Sunday to Saturday (VIBGYOR pattern for the color of bedsheet to be used) at ESIC hospitals.

Not to be confused with Mission Indradhanush, which is related to vaccination.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Barlow’s syndrome are true except:

choices.text: Handgrip manoeuvre quickens the onset of systolic click

questions.solution:
Handgrip maneuver delays the onset of the mid-systolic click which is heard on auscultation in Barlow’s syndrome (also known as mitral valve prolapse syndrome).

All the other statements regarding Barlow’s syndrome are true.

questions.text: The prothrombin time (PT) assay does not assess the function of:
questions.solution:
The prothrombin time (PT) assay does not assess the function of Factor VIII.

The prothrombin time (PT) assay assesses the function of the proteins in the extrinsic pathway:

factors VII, X, V, II, and fibrinogen.

Factor VIII is a protein involved in intrinsic pathway and its function is assessed by the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay.

PT assay- Tissue factor, phospholipids, and calcium are added to plasma and the time for a fibrin clot to form is recorded.

Related Pearl: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic male presents with acute onset abdominal pain and vomiting. His last alcohol binge was yesterday night. A blood panel reveals elevated pancreatic lipase and amylase levels by almost threefold. Which of the following signs can be seen during radiological imaging?
questions.solution:
The case scenario provided above is highly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All of the signs mentioned above can be seen in a case of acute pancreatitis.

 

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the condition shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Becker’s naevus is most commonly seen on the upper trunk.

Becker’s naevus:

  • Hyperpigmented, generally non-linear lesion
  • More common in males
  • Most lesions appear in the first two decades, classically at puberty
  • Frequently hypertrichotic
  • Commonest on the upper trunk
  • Can be associated with extracutaneous abnormalities like  aplasia or hypoplasia of the underlying breast tissue, pectoralis major muscle, lipoatrophy

questions.text: Corduroy sign in a sagittal CT of the spine is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Corduroy sign in a sagittal/coronal CT of the spine is suggestive of a vertebral hemangioma.

It occurs due to the replacement of the normal cancellous bone by thickened vertical trabeculae surrounded by fat marrow or vascular lacunae in intraosseous haemangiomas, mimicking the appearance of corduroy cloth.

The same pathology in an axial section will give a polka-dot appearance as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following is maintained in diastolic heart failure?
questions.solution:
In diastolic heart failure, the ejection fraction is maintained. Myocardial elasticity is reduced leading to reduced diastolic filling. Poor diastolic filling in turn results in an inadequate stroke volume.

Note: In systolic heart failure, the stroke volume is reduced because of weak ventricular contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not a characteristic feature of insulinoma?

choices.text: Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

questions.solution:
Watery diarrhea and hypokalemia is a feature of VIPoma (not insulinoma).

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

The most common malignant neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is gastrinoma.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: False negative normal APGAR score is seen in  __________.
questions.solution:
False-negative normal APGAR score is seen in maternal acidosis.

False-negative APGAR, i.e., normal Apgar score with fetal acidosis is seen in

  • Maternal acidosis
  • High fetal catecholamine levels
  • Some full-term infants

False-positive APGAR, i.e., no fetal acidosis but low Apgar score is seen in:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs - analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulphate
  • Acute cerebral edema
  • Spinal cord trauma
  • Diaphragmatic hernia
  • Choanal atresia
  • Congenital pneumonia and sepsis
  • Congenital myopathy/neuropathy
  • Hemorrhage/hypovolemia

Related Pearl: APGAR score

Ransohoff sign is seen in _________

CBD- Common bile duct

Yellow discoloration of the umbilical region is known as Ransohoff sign. It is seen in ruptured common bile duct.

questions.text: What does mosaicism mean?

choices.text: Presence of two or more chromosomal complements
Presence of more than two sex chromosomes
Totally different chromosome sets seen in dizygotic twins

questions.solution: Mosaicism refers to the presence of two or more cell populations with different chromosome complements. It occurs due to faults such as non-disjunction or loss of sex chromosome during mitosis in the early zygote.  As a result, different cell lineages with different chromosomal configurations are formed.

questions.text: Submandibular gland is divided into superficial and deep lobes by _______ muscle.
questions.solution:
Submandibular gland is divided into superficial and deep lobes by the mylohyoid muscle.

Submandibular gland:

  • The submandibular gland is irregular in shape and about the size of a walnut.
  • It consists of a larger superficial and a smaller deep part, continuous with each other around the posterior border of mylohyoid.

questions.text: Identify the parasite based on the image of its egg given below:
questions.solution:
The image shows a bile stained egg of whipworm.

Egg of whipworm (Trichuris trichiura):

  • Barrel shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing a non-segmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • The egg has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown
  • The eggs float in saturated salt solution.
  • Eggs are not infective for humans.

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Identify the hormone that is primarily responsible for gall bladder contraction and relaxation of sphincter of Oddi once food enters the duodenum:
questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin relaxes the sphincter of Oddi and causes contraction of gall bladder once chyme reaches the duodenum. These changes make the bile flow into the duodenum.

Cholecystokinin is secreted by the I cells in the duodenum and the upper jejunum. Its secretion is stimulated by the presence of protein degradation products and long chain fatty acids in chyme. In addition to causing bile flow, it also accounts for most of the pancreatic digestive enzyme secretion after a meal.

questions.text: Which of the following represents a line drawn from the medial canthus of eye to the angle of the mandible?
questions.solution:
The line described above is Ohngren’s line.

Ohngren’s classification:

  • Ohngren’s classification is used for maxillary carcinoma.
  • Ohngren’s line extends between medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible.
  • Tumors located anteroinferior (infra-structural lesions) to this line tend to present earlier and are thus more likely to be completely resected.
  • Tumors situated posterior and superior to this line (malignancies from ethmoid, frontal and sphenoid sinuses) tend to have an advanced presentation and are more likely to involve critical structures (like the orbit) and thus tend to have a poorer prognosis.

Other options:

  • Camper’s line: It is the line running from the ala of the nose to the tragus of the ear is termed as the ala-tragus line.
  • Cantlie’s line: It is the vertical plane that divides the liver into right and left lobes of the liver, it is the principal plane that is used during hepatectomy.
  • Donaldson’s line: It is a line extending from the lateral semi-circular canal bisecting the posterior semi-circular canal.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo 4 cycles of chemotherapy. After her first cycle, she developed thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 19,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. Oprelvekin is an IL-11 analog used in the prophylaxis and treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. IL-11 stimulates the megakaryocytes to mature into platelets.

Other options:

2) Filgrastim is a G-CSF (Granulocyte- Colony Stimulating Factor), which is used for neutropenia.

3) Darbepoetin alfa is a modified form of erythropoietin, which stimulates erythroid proliferation. It is used to treat anemia in patients with chronic renal failure, HIV-infected patients treated with zidovudine and in cancer patients treated with myelosuppressive cancer chemotherapy 

4)Intravenous immunoglobulins are prepared from pools of thousands of healthy donors and used in the treatment of a number of conditions like primary immunodeiciency disorders, Kawasaki disease, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, Guillain Barre syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, . They have no role in the treatment of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a D shaped pupil?
questions.solution:
Iridodialysis refers to detachment of the iris root from the ciliary body and is associated with a D-shaped pupil. A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery at the site of detachment.

Other options:

Festooned pupil - It is seen in posterior synechiae with the adhesion of the pupillary margin to the lens capsule.(option A)

Iris bombe(option D) refers to the forward bowing of the iris seen in closed-angle glaucoma with irido-lenticular contact and in seclusio pupillae with 360-degree posterior synechiae. Drainage of aqueous is blocked due to the irido-lenticular apposition and pressure of the accumulated aqueous causes the iris to bow forward.

Iridodonesis(option B) refers to a tremulous iris caused by a lack of support. It is seen in pseudophakia after cataract surgery and in lens dislocation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a lineage-specific T cell marker?
questions.solution:
CD3 is lineage specific for T cells.

Other options:

  • PAX-5: B cell transcription factor
  • CD 19: Lineage specific B cell marker
  • TdT (Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase): An enzyme expressed in both pre-B and pre-T cells

Subtyping of ALL into pre–B and pre–T cell types is based on lineage-specific markers, CD19 and CD3 respectively.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the Uhthoff’s phenomenon seen?
questions.solution:
Uhthoff's phenomenon is seen in optic neuritis. It refers to a transient visual obscuration on exertion and exposure to heat that resolves on resting or moving away from the heat source. It usually occurs while having a hot bath.

Other symptoms of optic neuritis include the following:

  • Visual loss – monocular, sudden, progressive and profound
  • Lowered dark adaptation
  • Visual obscuration in bright light
  • Reduced vividness of colours
  • Phosphenes – Movement and sound induced glowing sensations in the eye
  • Pulfrich’s phenomenon – Impaired depth perception, especially for moving objects
  • Pain – Mild dull eye ache. More marked in retrobulbar neuritis. Aggravated by eye movement.

questions.text: The number of ASHA visits after institutional vaginal delivery are ______
questions.solution:
ASHA home visits:

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1)
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS  (no visits on day 1 and day 3)

Note: The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs.250.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: Identify the sinus present in the structure marked in red color, in the image below:
questions.solution: The area marked ‘red ‘ represents the groove for transverse sinus present in the occipital bone.

questions.text: Hide-and-die syndrome is a feature of:
questions.solution:
The hide-and-die syndrome/Terminal burrowing behaviour is seen in some cases of hypothermic death.

The hypothermia victim attempts to protect himself from the cold by hiding himself in corners, cupboards or furniture. When the person is outdoors, he may burrow into snow. The behaviour is thought to result from disorientation due to hypothermia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a parameter obtained at the time of admission under Ranson’s prognostic criteria for non-gallstone pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Serum calcium levels are obtained after 48 hrs of admission under Ranson’s prognostic criteria for non-gallstone pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

 

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

questions.text: Which of the following is not found in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Heinz bodies are not found in multiple myeloma. They are inclusions within red blood cells composed of denatured hemoglobin found in G6PD deficiency.

The following findings are seen in the histological picture of multiple myeloma:

  • Malignant plasma cells - perinuclear clearing due to a prominent Golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus.
  • Other cytologic variants with intracellular accumulation of intact or partially degraded protein.
  • Flame cells with fiery red cytoplasm
  • Mott cells with multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets
  • Cells containing a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.
  • The globular cytoplasmic inclusions referred to as Russell bodies or nuclear inclusions known as Dutcher bodies.

questions.text: A cochlea with a well-developed basilar turn and an incomplete partition of the second and apical turns is called:
questions.solution:
The incomplete partition between the scalae of the second and the apical turns of the cochlea with a well-developed basal turn is characteristic of Mondini dysplasia/malformation.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most effective form of chlorine for water disinfection?
questions.solution:
The disinfectant property of the bleaching powder is due to hypochlorous acid.

The active component of bleaching powder, CaOCl2 , is hypochlorous acid.

Action of chlorine: When chlorine is added to water, there is formation of hydrochloric and hypochlorous acids.

The hydrochloric acid is neutralized by the alkalinity of the water. The hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen ions and hypochlorite ions, as follows:

H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl

HOCl → H + OCl

The disinfecting action of chlorine is mainly due to hypochlorous acid, and to a small extent due to the hypochlorite ions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the angular gyrus?

choices.text: Conversion of written word into its auditory form
Connects speech articulation and auditory processing centres

questions.solution:
The angular gyrus is situated behind the Wernicke area and converts written word forms into auditory representations. These auditory representations are then processed by the Wernicke area.

Other options:

  • The Wernicke area is concerned with comprehension of auditory and visual information.
  • The Broca area processes information from the Wernicke area into a detailed and coordinated pattern for vocalization.
  • The arcuate fasciculus connects the Wernicke area and the Broca area.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist?
questions.solution:
Rizatriptan is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist.

Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists.

Other drugs used for the treatment of acute migraine are:

  • Simple analgesics: Acetaminophen, aspirin
  • NSAIDs: naproxen, Ibuprofen, diclofenac, tolfenamic acid.
  • Ergot derivatives: non-selective 5HT 1 agonists given oral, nasal or parenteral
  • Dopamine receptor antagonist: Metoclopramide, prochlorperazine

Fremanezumab and Galcanezumab are humanized monoclonal antibody against calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) approved by FDA in 2018 for the preventive treatment of migraine in adults.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side along with dysphagia, and dysarthria, and frequently falls towards the left side on walking. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient having left-sided Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, dysarthria, ataxia towards left and right-sided loss of pain and temperature is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome.

Wallenberg’s syndrome, otherwise known as the lateral medullary syndrome, is a type of ischemic stroke of the brainstem. The symptoms and the corresponding tracts affected are shown below: 

Tract affected Symptoms
Descending tract and nucleus of CN V  Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
IX and X CN Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord(dysarthria), diminished gag reflex causing dysphagia
The nucleus of tractus solitarius Ipsilateral loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus   Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract Ipsilateral ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis (decreased sweating)
Lateral spinothalamic tract  Impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

It can be caused by occlusion of vessels like the vertebral artery, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), Superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries. The most commonly involved are the vertebral artery and PICA.

Other options:

Dejerine syndrome is otherwise known as medial medullary syndrome. It occurs due to occlusion of the vertebral artery or its branch. There is paralysis of the ipsilateral tongue (face is spared) and contralateral limbs, as well as impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense of the contralateral half of the body.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: The grade of the given urological condition and the surgical treatment option with the best outcome for this condition depicted in the image is

choices.text: Grade 4, Nephrectomy of the Damaged Kidney to Prevent Recurrent UTI

questions.solution:
The image shows a Grade V vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). The surgical treatment for this is ureteric reimplantation & it has 95-97% cure rates. Here, the ureter is reimplanted in a different site in the bladder from the normal anatomic site.

As VUR is autosomal dominant, USG screening is done is other siblings to rule out the disease.

However, micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) remains the investigation of choice.

Scars can be ruled out using DMSA Renal Scintigraphy.

VUR is the most common cause of renal scarring, and hence, scarring is considered one of the indications of VUR.

The other surgical modalities mentioned in the options have no role in isolated Vesicoureteric Reflux.

Grading of vesicoureteral reﬂux:

  • Grade I: VUR into a non-dilated ureter
  • Grade II: VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation
  • Grade III: VUR into dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices
  • Grade IV: VUR into a grossly dilated tortuous ureter
  • Grade V: Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary impression.

questions.text: Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants at birth because of a transient deficiency of ________.
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants because of a transient deficiency of factor IX.

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

questions.text: Which of the following is a pure progesterone antagonist?
questions.solution:
Onapristone is a pure progesterone antagonist.

Other options:

  • Ormeloxifene is a non-steroidal Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM).
  • Mifepristone is a Selective Progesterone Receptor Modulator (SPRM), though it primarily acts primarily as a competitive receptor antagonist for progesterone receptors, it may have some agonist activity in certain contexts. Thus, it is not a pure progesterone antagonist.
  • Ulipristal is also an SPRM which is a partial agonist-antagonist of progesterone receptors.

questions.text: Which among the following matches is true?
questions.solution:
Nazer’s prognostic index is a method to assess the severity of hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease in which there is defective copper biliary excretion from liver cells.

Wilsons disease:

  • ATP7B mutation
  • Presence of Kayser Fleischer Ring
  • Most specific investigation – Urinary excretion of copper
  • Gold standard investigation is – Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays
  • Nazer’s prognostic index: to assess the severity of hepatic decompensation

Other options:

  • Zinc – Stabilises insulin
  • Chromium – Potentiates insulin

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about gastrointestinal stromal tumors?

choices.text: Originates from interstitial cells of Cajal
Most common mesenchymal tumors of GIT
Mainstay of treatment is medical management
Overexpression of c-kit proto oncogene is seen in most of the cases

questions.solution:
The mainstay of treatment in gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is complete surgical resection.

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are the most common sarcomatous tumors of the GI tract. They are derived from the interstitial cells of Cajal or intestinal pacemaker cells.

They are usually found in the stomach (40-60%), small intestine (30%), and colon (15%).

Overexpression of c-kit proto oncogene is seen in 95% of these tumors and CD34+ in 60-70% of tumors.

The malignant potential of these tumors is assessed based on tumor size and mitotic activity.

The mainstay of treatment is complete surgical resection. Depending on tumor size, resection can include wide local excision, enucleation, sleeve gastrectomy, or total gastrectomy, with or without en bloc resection of adjacent organs.

questions.text: Which among the following is more common in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis when compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Esophageal dysmotility is more commonly seen in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) compared to diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Systemic sclerosis is divided into two based on the patterns of involvement - diffuse and limited.

Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis is characteristically associated with CREST syndrome, which includes calcinosis cutis, Raynaud’s phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly and telangiectasia. 

Skin involvement, interstitial lung disease (Option C), myopathy (Option B), and scleroderma renal crisis (Option D) are more common in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc) than limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

The incidence of ischemic digital ulcers, CREST features, and primary biliary cirrhosis is more in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The frequency of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is equal in both types.

 

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is involved in uncoupling oxidation and phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Thermogenin, also called the uncoupling protein 1, uncouples oxidation and phosphorylation in the electron transport chain. It does this by forming a proton conductance channel in the inner mitochondrial membrane, thereby allowing protons to bypass ATP synthase and enter the mitochondrial matrix. As a result, ATP is not generated in the mitochondria though oxidation of NADH and FADH takes place with production of heat.

Thermogenin is present in brown adipose tissue and is involved in the generation of heat. In humans, it’s particularly active in the newborn.

questions.text: Which of the following gestational period qualifies to be called a post-term pregnancy according to ACOG guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the ACOG guidelines, a post-term pregnancy is defined as one reaching to or extending beyond 42 0/7 weeks (42 completed weeks) of gestation.

The guidelines label the pregnancy according to the gestational age as follows:

Preterm pregnancy: Less than 37 0/7 weeks

Early term pregnancy: 37 0/7 weeks to 38 6/7 weeks

Full-term pregnancy: 39 0/7 weeks to 40 6/7 weeks

Late-term pregnancy: 41 0/7 weeks to 41 6/7 weeks

Post-term pregnancy: 42 0/7 weeks or higher

questions.text: Epsilon wave is a characteristic feature of:
questions.solution: The epsilon wave is a characteristic finding seen in the ECG of a patient with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy. It is a small positive deflection buried at the end of the QRS complex. T wave inversions in V1–V3 is seen 85% of patients with ARVC.

questions.text: A 60 year old man presented with dull aching pain in the lower limbs. His serum alkaline phosphatase level was found to be raised and his x-ray shows the following sign. This condition is characterised by:
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows the blade of grass sign/ candle flame sign  which is characteristic of Paget’s disease. The given clinical scenario of elderly person with dull aching pain and raised serum alkaline phosphatase level also points to the diagnosis of Paget’s disease.

Paget’s disease is characterized by:

  • Increased bone turnover
  • Enlargement and thickening of the bone,
  • Abnormal internal architecture
  • Brittle bones

Other options:

  • Impaired bone mineralization- Osteomalacia
  • Impaired vit-D metabolism - Osteomalacia
  • Abnormal type 1 collagen- Osteogenesis imperfecta

questions.text: A pathology student describes a microbial defence mechanism where neutrophils lose their nuclei. Which specific process is being referred to by the student?
questions.solution:
Neutrophils undergo cell death and lose their nuclei during the formation of neutrophil extracellular traps.

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs): Extracellular fibrillar networks that provide a high concentration of antimicrobial substances at sites of infection and prevent the spread of the microbes by trapping them in the fibrils.

  • Viscous meshwork of nuclear chromatin that concentrates antimicrobial peptides and enzymes.
  • In the process of NET formation, the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost, leading to cell death.
  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly SLE.

The following image represents the process of microbial killing using the neutrophil extracellular trap. A neutrophil granulocyte (yellow) has ejected a NET (green) to capture bacteria (purple). A red blood cell (orange) is also trapped in the NET.


Other options: Various steps in leukocyte recruitment during inflammatory response:

Option A-Diapedesis - It is the migration of leukocytes through the endothelium towards the site of injury or infection, stimulated by the chemokines.

Option B-Margination- The process of leukocyte redistribution where more white cells assume a peripheral position along the endothelial surface.

Option D-Oxidative burst- Microbes are killed after phagocytosis by producing reactive oxygen species (ROS). NADPH oxidase oxidises NADPH and, in the process, reduces oxygen to superoxide anion (O2 • ). In neutrophils, this oxidative reaction is called the respiratory/oxidative burst.

questions.text: A patient’s ABG was consistent with the curve X in the nomogram given below with serum Na: 138 mEq/L, serum Cl: 110 mEq/L and serum HCO3-: 19 mEq/L. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario shows a normal gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA (renal tubular acidosis).

The anion gap in this patient can be calculated as Na+ – (Cl- + HCO3-) = 138– (110+19) = 138 - 129 = 9.

The normal anion gap ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L, with an average of 10 mmol/L. Among the given options, only renal tubular acidosis is associated with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

All of the other options cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Methanol
  • Uremia (chronic kidney failure)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol, Propylene glycol
  • Infection, Iron, Isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Salicylates

questions.text: Which of the following biomarkers is used in the calculation of the risk of malignancy index for ovarian cancers?
questions.solution:
Risk of malignancy index (RMI) is a tool used to differentiate between benign and malignant ovarian mass, and cancer antigen 125 is used in the calculation of its value. A score above 200 indicates that the lesion is more likely to be malignant than benign.

Risk of Malignancy Index:

RMI = U x M x CA125

  • U= Ultrasound score. The ultrasound result is scored 1 point for each of the following characteristics: multilocular cysts, solid areas, metastases, ascites and bilateral lesions. U = 0 (for an ultrasound score of 0), U = 1 (for an ultrasound score of 1), U = 3 (for an ultrasound score of 2–5).

  • M= Menopausal status. The menopausal status is scored as 1 = pre-menopausal and 3 = post-menopausal

  • CA125= Serum CA125 level (IU/ml)

questions.text: Pendular knee jerk is due to defect in:
questions.solution:
Lesion to neocerebellum leads to pendular knee jerk.

It also leads to 

  • Hypotonia
  • Pendular knee jerk
  • Dysmetria
  • Dysdiakokinesia
  • Scanning speech

Option A:

Ischaemic stroke – Brisk D.T.R. with Babinski sign

Option C:

Archicerebellum- Truncal ataxia, Titubation

Option D:

Paleocerebellum – Gait ataxia, Loss of tandem gait

questions.text: A patient with narcolepsy will have which of the following characteristic changes in sleep?
questions.solution:
Narcolepsy is characterized by decreased REM latency.

It is characterized by the tetrad of: 

  1. Excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. Cataplexy (sudden loss of muscle tone)
  3. Hypnagogic/hypnopompic hallucinations
  4. Sleep paralysis

The hallmark of narcolepsy is decreased REM latency, i.e. decreased latent period before the first REM period occurs. Normal REM latency is 90-100 minutes. In narcolepsy, REM-sleep usually occurs within 10 minutes of the onset of sleep (sleep-onset REM).

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution: The above instrument is Desjardin’s choledocholithotomy forceps and is used for bile duct stone removal. It may also be used during removal of kidney, ureteral, or bladder stone.

questions.text: During an autopsy, you notice that the body is in a pugilistic attitude. The cause behind this is?
questions.solution:
Pugilistic attitude (boxing, fencing, or defense attitude ): The posture of a body which has been exposed to high amount of heat e.g. in case of burns.

This occurs due to the coagulation of the muscle proteins and dehydration. It is more marked in the flexors than extensors.

  • The legs are flexed at the hips and knees,
  • The arms are flexed at the elbows and wrists
  • Fingers are clawed
  • Head slightly extended
  • Marked opisthotonus

questions.text: Which of the following staphylomas is located at the limbus and lined by the root of iris?
questions.solution:
Intercalary staphyloma is located at the limbus and lined by the root of iris along with the anterior-most part of the ciliary body. It extends up to 2 mm behind the limbus. It is caused by lesions that weaken the globe in the limbal region such as marginal corneal ulcer, peripheral corneal injury, anterior scleritis and poor wound apposition after cataract surgery.

Other options:

  • Anterior staphyloma involves the cornea and pseudo-cornea lined internally by the iris and externally by corneal epithelium is formed.
  • Ciliary staphyloma involves the ciliary zone up to 8 mm behind the limbus. It is internally lined by the ciliary body and has a bluish colour with a lobulated surface.
  • Equatorial staphyloma is located approximately 14 mm behind the limbus and is lined internally by the choroid.

questions.text: The structure shown in the image given below is found in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
The image is of typical endoflagella which is a characteristic feature  of Spirochetes such as Leptospira, Treponema and Borrelia.

Endoflagella (axial filament)

  • Flagella like organelles
  • Originate at each end of the cell and wind around the axis of the cell and interdigitate at its center
  • Lie in the periplasmic space between the inner cell membrane and the outer membrane

Related Pearl: Types of flagella:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are contraindicated in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution: Halothane can sensitize the heart to the arrhythmogenic action of catecholamines (which are elevated in patients with pheochromocytoma). Thus, in these patients, ventricular arrhythmias may occur when halothane is given for anesthesia.

questions.text: The structure that lies superficial to the flexor retinaculum is _________
questions.solution:
Palmaris longus tendon passes superficial to the flexor retinaculum.

  • The flexor retinaculum is a strong, short and broad, fibrous band, measuring 2.5–3 cm both transversely and proximodistal.
  • It is attached medially to the pisiform bone and the hook of the hamate bone. Laterally, it splits into superficial and deep laminae.

The structures lying deep to the flexor retinaculum are

  • Lateral compartment:
    • Flexor carpi radialis
  • Medial compartment:
    • Median nerve
    • Flexor pollicis longus
    • 4 tendons each of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor digitorum profundus

Structures lying superficial to the flexor retinaculum are

  • Palmaris longus tendon
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve
  • Palmar cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar nerve
  • Ulnar vessels

questions.text: Which of the following does not inhibit the action of cytochrome oxidase?
questions.solution:
Molecular oxygen is required for the functioning of cytochrome oxidase, also known as complex IV of the electron transport chain. The enzyme is blocked by carbon monoxide, cyanide, and hydrogen sulphide. Adenosine triphosphate allosterically inhibits the enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following is the hormonal contraceptive in Norplant II?
questions.solution:
The hormonal contraceptive present in Norplant II/Jadelle is Levonorgestrel.

Norplant II/Jadelle is a subdermal implant with two rods, each containing 70 mg of levonorgestrel. The hormone is released at a rate of 50 mcg per day. It provides contraception for 3-5 years.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: In a pregnant woman, on performing Leopold’s third maneuver, a hard, round and movable mass is felt. What does the finding suggest with regard to the presenting part?
questions.solution:
The finding suggests that the presenting part is an unengaged fetal head.

Leopold’s third maneuver (Pawlik’s grip): It helps in the confirmation of fetal presentation. It involves grasping the lower part of the maternal abdomen with the thumb and fingers of one hand. Palpation of a hard and round mass indicates that the presenting part is the fetal head. A movable mass suggests that the presenting part is not engaged. If the presenting part is breech, it is felt as a large nodular mass.

The other Leopold’s maneuvers are as follows:

Leopold’s first maneuver (fundal grip): It helps in the identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

Leopold’s second maneuver (lateral grip): It can be used to determine fetal orientation based on whether the back is facing anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly. The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen and gentle deep pressure is exerted. The fetal back is felt as a hard-resistant structure and the fetal limbs are felt as multiple small irregular parts.

Leopold’s fourth maneuver (pelvic grip): It helps in determining the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: Which of the following chromosomal anomalies is a poor prognostic factor in AML?
questions.solution:
del(7q) is an unfavorable prognostic feature in patients with acute myeloid leukemia(AML).

Prognostic implications of chromosomal abnormalities in AML

Favorable prognosis:

  • t(8;21); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
  • Inv(16) or t(16;16); CBFβ
  • NPM1 mutation
  • CEBPA mutation

Poor prognosis:

  • inv(3)
  • t(6;9)
  • del(7q)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic finding of pseudohypoaldosteronism type II?

choices.text: Gain of function mutation of WNK1 gene

questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia) is a hallmark finding of pseudohypoaldosteronism type II (Gordon syndrome).

Gordon syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease due to gain of function mutation of WNK1 and WNK4 genes (serine-threonine kinases). This leads to increased co-transporter activity, excessive chloride and sodium reabsorption, and volume expansion.

It is characterized by short stature, intellectual impairment, dental abnormalities, muscle weakness, severe hypertension by the third decade of life, low fractional excretion of sodium, normal renal function, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, and low renin and aldosterone levels.

Related Pearl: Causes of Secondary Hypertension

Renal parenchymal

Glomerulonephritis, renal cysts, renal tumors

Renovascular

Renal artery stenosis, arteriosclerotic, fibromuscular dysplasia

Adrenal

Primary aldosteronism, Cushing’s syndrome, pheochromocytoma

Aortic coarctation

 

Obstructive sleep apnea

  

Pre-eclampsia/ eclampsia

 

Neurogenic

Psychogenic, polyneuritis (acute porphyria, lead poisoning), acute increased ICP, acute spinal cord section

Endocrine

Hypothyroidism, hyperthyroidism, hypercalcemia, acromegaly

Medications

High-dose estrogens, adrenal steroids, appetite suppressants, cyclosporine, tricyclic antidepressants, MAO inhibitors, NSAIDS

Mendelian forms

Liddle’s syndrome, Gordon’s syndrome, MEN 2A & 2B

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, diagnosed with bipolar disorder is under treatment with lithium for the past 2 months. She now presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination and a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus was made. The administration of desmopressin did not increase the specific gravity of urine. Which is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) is amiloride.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index hence regular determination of serum concentrations is important. Its use is approved by FDA in acute mania and the prevention of recurrences of bipolar illness in adults or adolescents.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • CNS toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into collecting duct cells and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI.

Other options:

Option A: Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory sodium as well as lithium reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Option C: Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Thiazide diuretics also lead to lithium toxicity.

Option D: Chlorpropamide is a long-acting oral sulfonylurea preferred for central diabetes insipidus owing to its enhancing action on circulating vasopressin.

questions.text: A mother presents with fever and right-sided breast pain in the puerperal period. Examination reveals diffuse tenderness and erythema of the right breast without any localized firmness or fluctuance. How is this condition managed?

choices.text: Cessation of breast feeding on the affected side

questions.solution:
The history and findings suggest a diagnosis of lactational mastitis which is managed with antibiotics. Beta-lactamase resistant penicillins such as cloxacillin, dicloxacillin or flucloxacillin are given. If resistant staphylococcal infection is prevalent and suspected, vancomycin, clindamycin or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be given.

Lactational mastitis:

The most common organism causing breast infection is Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Symptoms appear in 3rd/4th week
  • Infection is almost always unilateral
  • The immediate source of organism that causes mastitis is always the infant's nose and throat (Not GIT).
  • Predisposing factors: fissures/abrasions/cracks in nipple

Other options:

  • Breast feeding is to be continued as it poses no risk to the infant. It also helps avoid deleterious effects such as painful breast engorgement and breast abscess.
  • Incision and drainage is done only if breast abscess is present.

questions.text: The cytopathic effect of mumps virus is:
questions.solution:
The cytopathic effects of mumps virus include cell rounding and giant cell formation.

Cytopathic effect- cell changes seen in host cell when infected by viruses. Some viruses produce characteristic cytopathic effects while multiplying in cell culture which helps in diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

Morphological changes in the cells that are caused by viruses are known as cytopathic effects (CPE) and the viruses causing these CPEs are known as cytopathogenic viruses. These CPEs can be detected by a light microscope.

Type of cytopathic effect

Virus

Rapid crenation of cells and degeneration of the cells

Enterovirus

Syncytium/multinucleated giant cell formation

Measles, mumps, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

Discrete focal degeneration

Herpes virus

Large granular clumps resembling grapes

Adenovirus

Cytoplasmic vacuolation

Simian virus 40 (SV 40)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection?
questions.solution:
Tubal block is not an indication for intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), which involves injecting a single chosen sperm into the cytoplasm of the oocyte.

Related Pearl: Indications for various procedures in Infertility treatment

Indications of artificial insemination with husband's semen:

  • Chronic medical disorder
  • Oligospermia after sperm washout
  • Impotency or ejaculatory failure
  • Premature ejaculation, retrograde ejaculation
  • Hypospadias
  • Antisperm antibodies in the cervical mucus
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Frozen sperm: If the husband needs to undergo radiotherapy or chemotherapy or is not available at the time of ovulation
  • X–Y fractionation of sperms for sex selection, in a genetic and chromosomal abnormality
  • HIV positive male or female

Indications for Intra-cytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) and gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT):

  • Sperm count of less than 5 million/mL
  • Absent or reduced sperm motility
  • Abnormal sperm morphology
  • Previous failed IVF
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Failure to penetrate zona by sperm as seen in IVF

questions.text: What is the lowest part of the cervix palpated by an examining finger when the uterus is anteverted and anteflexed:

choices.text: Either posterior lip or external os

questions.solution:
In an anteverted anteflexed uterus, the lowest part of the cervix is the anterior lip. This is because the external os of the cervix is directed downward and backward.

In a retroverted uterus, the external os of the cervix is directed downward and forward. As a result, the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or the posterior lip.

questions.text: Which of the following fertility indicator can change with changes in age specific mortality rates?
questions.solution:
Net reproduction rate can change with changes in age specific mortality rates. General fertility rate, total fertility rate, and gross reproduction rate are not dependent on age specific mortality rate.

Net Reproduction Rate: It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rates.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: The finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a chocolate cyst, which is seen in ovarian endometriosis.

The cysts form secondary to endometriotic implants in the ovarian stroma that bleed periodically and undergo shedding.

Spontaneous cyst rupture, with the release of thick, tarry brownish fluid, can lead to acute peritonitis, and this may be mistaken for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, appendicitis, diverticulitis, or torsion of a tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is activated by N-acetyl glutamate?
questions.solution:
N-acetyl glutamate is an allosteric activator of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I). CPS I catalyses the rate limiting step in urea synthesis and is present in the mitochondria. This reaction uses up two molecules of ATP to generate one molecule of carbamoyl phosphate.

Other options:

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase II is the rate limiting enzyme in pyrimidine synthesis. It is inhibited by UTP and activated by ATP and PRPP.

CPS I  CPS II
Rate-limiting enzyme of urea cycle Rate limiting step of pyrimidine synthesis
Found in mitochondria Found in cytosol
Uses ammonia as nitrogen source Uses glutamine as nitrogen source
Requires N-acetyl glutamate as positive allosteric activator Doesn’t require N-acetyl glutamate

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: Absence of which of the following milestones in a four-year-old child is called delayed development?

choices.text: Plays in group with other children

questions.solution:
Playing in a group with other children is a social milestone appearing typically by 36 months.

This child, being 48 months old, has a delayed development if it is absent.

Dressing and undressing (without help), drawing a triangle, and asking the meaning of words appear by 60 months (5 years).

questions.text: Identify the low-risk human papilloma viruses among the following:
questions.solution:
HPV 4, 6 and 11 are low-risk HPVs i.e. they have low malignant potential.

HPV 16 and 18 are high-risk HPVs. They express oncogenic proteins like E6 and E7 that cause neoplastic transformation by:

  • Inactivating tumor suppressors
  • Activating cyclins
  • Inhibiting apoptosis
  • Preventing cellular senescence

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon depicted in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image depicts gate control of pain. Dorsal horn neurons that transmit pain signals are inhibited by collaterals from cutaneous mechanoreceptors and the intensity of pain felt is lessened. This is how rubbing or shaking an injured area decreases pain.

Clinical relevance: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is based on the gate control phenomenon and uses electrodes to activate A alpha and A beta fibers near the site of injury. This inhibits transmission of pain signals in the spinal cord and alleviates the pain.

questions.text: In Goodpasture’s syndrome the antibodies are directed against:
questions.solution:
In Goodpasture’s syndrome (GPS) autoantibodies are directed against the non-collagenous (NC1) domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV, which are predominantly present in the alveolar and glomerular basement membranes.

The antibodies cause inﬂammatory destruction of the basement membrane in renal glomeruli and pulmonary alveoli, giving rise to glomerulonephritis and hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis.

questions.text: The chemokine group that primarily acts on neutrophils is:
questions.solution:
C-X-C chemokines act primarily on neutrophils.

Chemokines are a family of small (8 to 10 kD) proteins that act primarily as chemoattractants for specific types of leukocytes. They are classified into four major groups, according to the arrangement of cysteine (C) residues in the proteins:

C-X-C chemokines-

  • Act primarily on neutrophils
  • IL-8 is typical of this group secreted by activated macrophages, endothelial cells, and other cell types causes activation and chemotaxis of neutrophils, with limited activity on monocytes and eosinophils.
  • Most important inducers are microbial products and other cytokines, mainly IL-1 and TNF

C-C chemokines-

  • Generally attract monocytes, eosinophils, basophils and lymphocytes, but are not as potent chemoattractants for neutrophils
  • Include monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP-1), eotaxin, macrophage inflammatory protein-1α (MIP-1α), and RANTES (regulated and normal T-cell expressed and secreted) eotaxin selectively recruits eosinophils

C chemokines-

  • The C chemokines (e.g., lymphotactin) are relatively specific for lymphocytes.

CX3C chemokines-

  • The only known member of this class is fractalkine.
  • This chemokine exists in two forms: cell surface-bound protein- promotes strong adhesion of monocytes and T cells; soluble form- potent chemoattractant activity for monocytes and T cells

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a skin disorder in the neonate?
questions.solution:
Miliaria is a disorder due to blockage of eccrine sweat ducts.

It is subdivided into three subtypes dependent on the level of blockage:

  • miliaria crystallina (stratum corneum)
  • miliaria rubra (mid‐epidermal)
  • miliaria profunda (dermal–epidermal junction)

Miliaria rubra and miliaria crystallina are common in neonates.

The other three conditions are considered physiological:

Erythema neonatorum- Generalized hyperaemia developing a few hours after birth is usually known as erythema neonatorum. It fades away spontaneously within 24–48 h.

Vernix caseosa- It is a whitish, greasy film that covers the skin at birth, comprising of lipids and antimicrobial peptides. It normally dries rapidly and starts to flake off within a few hours of birth.

Cutis marmorata- Newborn infants who are subjected to cooling will show distinct marbling of the skin which disappears on rewarming.

Cutis marmorata telangiectatica congenita is a distinct vascular developmental disorder, and is easily distinguished as it is fixed.

questions.text: Rockall score is used for prognosis of patients with:
questions.solution:
Rockall scoring system is used for assessing the prognosis of patients with upper GI bleeding.

Blatchford Score and Rockall scoring system are used risk stratification systems for UGI bleeding.

Rockall Score:

  • Age (<60 years, 60-79 years, >80 years.
  • Comorbid disease (cardiac, hepatic, renal, or disseminated cancer)
  • The magnitude of hemorrhage (SBP <100 mmHg, PR >100 bpm) on presentation
  • Transfusion requirement
  • Endoscopic findings (Mallory-Weiss tears, non-malignant lesions, or malignant lesions)
  • Stigmata of recent bleed

Mortality rate and rate of rebleeding increase as the score increases (a score of 8 or more is considered a very high risk).

questions.text: A 40-year old woman underwent routine mammographic screening for breast cancer. The radiologist reported the mammographic lesion found as BIRADS grade 3. This categorization implies that the lesion has a _______% chance of being malignant.
questions.solution:
A lesion reported as BIRADS grade 3, has a <2% chance of being malignant. 

BIRADS Grade:

  • Grade 3: >0% but ≤2% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 4:
    • 4a: >2% to ≤10% chance of being malignant
    • 4b: >10% to ≤50% chance of being malignant
    • 4c: >50% to <95% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 5: ≥95% chance of being malignant

questions.text: What is the most common type of degenerative change in a fibroid?
questions.solution:
Hyaline degeneration is the most common degenerative change seen in fibroids. It is caused by poor blood supply when the tumor outgrows its blood supply. Eosinophilic hyaline tissue is deposited between smooth muscle cells and changes appear first at the center of the mass.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the computed tomography (CT) image provided below?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CT pulmonary angiography showing a pulmonary (saddle) embolism.

CT pulmonary angiography using multi-detector CT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. 

An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses. Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature.

Depending on the size of the embolus, it can occlude the main pulmonary artery; straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus); or pass out into the smaller, branching arteries.

The below image shows a CT thorax of saddle embolism.

Other options

Option A- Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as an increase in vascular resistance of the pulmonary circulation involving a combination of vasoconstriction and remodeling of small vessels. Hemodynamically, it is defined as a systolic pulmonary artery pressure of more than 35 mmHg or a mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) >20 mmHg

A diameter of the main pulmonary artery at the level of its bifurcation of more than 29 mm helps in the diagnosis of PH.

Option B- Thoracic aortic aneurysm occurs due to the intrinsic weakness of the aortic wall and they rarely manifest with symptoms. A CECT scan is the most widely used for diagnosis and it assesses the size, extent, and location of the aneurysm.

The below image shows a CT scan of a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. The black arrow is the aorta and the white arrow is blood in the thorax.

Option D- The mural thrombus of the aorta is the thrombus attached to the wall of an aorta. They occur in the normal or minimally atherosclerotic vessel. The modality for diagnosis of mural thrombi is CT or MRI angiography.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Related Pearl: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1

Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6

Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 

 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about Volkmann contracture:

choices.text: It is a complication of supracondylar fracture humerus
It involves contracture of palmar fascia
Fingers can be straightened when the wrist is extended
Associated with damage to the radial nerve

questions.solution:
Volkmann’s ischemic contracture (VIC) is one of the complications of supracondylar fracture humerus.

Volkmann’s ischemic contracture (VIC):

  • VIC results from  impaired circulation due to injuries at or below the elbow
  • There is fibrosis of forearm muscles and shortening of the tendons causing flexion deformity of the fingers
  • The fingers can be straightened by flexing the wrist as there is relaxation of the long flexors
  • There can be associated damage to the ulnar or median nerve
  • Finger movement can be restored by tendon transfer and lengthening of the tendons

questions.text: In a young boy who presented with molluscum contagiosum, it was noted that new lesions appeared at the site of scratching. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.solution:
The phenomenon where new lesions appeared at the site of scratching in a young boy presenting with molluscum contagiosum is pseudo-Koebner response.

Koebner/isomorphic response (Option B) refers to the appearance of new skin lesions in previously normal skin subjected to trauma. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.  It is more likely to occur when the disease is active.

Pseudo-Koebnerization refers to the appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury, resulting from the spread of an infective agent. It is seen in plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, 

Koebner phenomenon is seen in conditions like

  • Psoriasis
  • Vitiligo
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen planus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other options: 

Option-C: Reverse Koebner phenomenon refers to the disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis.

Option-D: Isotopic response is the emergence of a new lesion at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis such as granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text: How does botulinum toxin cause flaccid paralysis?
questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by inhibiting acetylcholine release at the presynaptic membrane. It does this by cleaving proteins in the presynaptic terminal that are necessary for release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft. One of the following proteins is targeted according to the toxin subtype.

  • Synaptosome associated protein (SNAP-25) required for fusion of vesicle containing neurotransmitter with the presynaptic membrane
  • Vesicle associated membrane protein, also called synaptobrevin
  • Syntaxin, a membrane protein involved in exocytosis

Other options:

Curare group of drugs compete with acetylcholine for binding to acetylcholine receptors.

Succinylcholine causes depolarising blockade of muscle fibres by continuous stimulation of acetylcholine receptors at the motor end plate.

Related Pearl: Agents affecting neuromuscular transmission

Example

Action

Effect on Neuromuscular Transmission

Botulinum toxin

Blocks release of ACh from presynaptic terminal

Total blockade of terminals

Curare

Competes with ACh for receptors on motor end plate

Decreases size of EPP; maximal doses produce end plate paralysis of respiratory muscles and death

Neostigmine

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase

Prolongs and enhances action of ACh at

muscle end plate

Hemicholinium

Blocks reuptake of choline

Depletes ACh stores from presynaptic terminal
