questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of a constant feeling of lump in his throat, but there is no difficulty in swallowing. The symptoms are worse when he tries to swallow his own rather than during eating or drinking. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of globus syndrome, which is a functional esophageal disorder characterized by a sensation of a lump or foreign body in the throat.

All other options can be ruled out as they are causes of true (organic) dysphagia.

Globus syndrome:

Globus sensation is a functional esophageal disorder characterized by a sensation of a lump, retained food bolus, or tightness in the throat that is not due to an underlying structural lesion, gastroesophageal reflux disease, mucosal abnormality, or an esophageal motility disorder.

The pathogenesis of globus sensation is unclear. Visceral hypersensitivity, abnormalities of the upper esophageal sphincter (UES), psychological and psychiatric disorders, and reflux have all been implicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ER after a blunt facial trauma following an RTA. There is malocclusion. On examination, there is bruising over the palate. A plain CT revealed craniofacial dysjunction. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
Ecchymosis in the palate in the region of the greater palatine arteries is termed Guerin’s sign.

Other options:

  • Battle’s sign: Ecchymosis overlying the mastoid indicative of a temporal bone fracture.
  • Destot’s sign: Superficial hematoma presenting as an ecchymosis located above the inguinal ligament or in the scrotum or thigh. It is indicative of pelvic fractures.
  • Fox’s sign: Bruising over the upper aspect of the thigh indicative of acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Desmoplasia in a tumor refers to:
questions.solution:
Desmoplasia refers to the formation of abundant collagenous stroma in the tumor. It makes the tumor stony hard/ scirrhous.

Basic components of tumors:

  • Neoplastic cells that constitute the tumor parenchyma- determine the classification of tumors and their biologic behavior
  • Reactive stroma made up of connective tissue, blood vessels- determine their growth and spread
  • Variable numbers of cells of the adaptive and innate immune system

Connective tissue in the tumor can be:

  • Scanty- it makes the neoplasm soft and fleshy
  • Abundant- in some tumors, the parenchymal cells stimulate the formation of an abundant collagenous stroma (desmoplasia). It makes the tumor stony hard or scirrhous. e.g. some cancers of the female breast.

questions.text: Which of the following stimulates renin secretion from the juxtaglomerular cells?

choices.text: Increased Sodium and Chloride concentration in the distal renal tubule

questions.solution:
Unilateral renal artery stenosis is associated with increased renin secretion.

The arterial stenosis reduces the blood pressure in the afferent arterioles which in turn stimulates renin secretion through the intrarenal baroreceptor mechanism. This mechanism causes an increase in renin secretion when the arteriolar pressure at the level of juxtaglomerular (JG) cells falls and vice-versa. The increased renin secretion leads to secondary renal hypertension which is also known as Goldblatt hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: The renin secretion is inversely proportional to the amount of sodium and chloride ions in the distal renal tubules. Thus an increase in these concentrations causes a decrease in renin secretion.

Option B: Increased level of vasopressin leads to inhibition of renin secretion.

Option D: Increased level of angiotensin II inhibits the secretion of renin via direct action on JG cells.

Related Pearl: Factors that affect renin secretion

Stimulatory

  • Increased sympathetic activity via renal nerves
  • Increased circulating catecholamines
  • Prostaglandins
  • Na+ depletion
  • Diuretics
  • Upright posture
  • Hemorrhage
  • Hypotension
  • Dehydration
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Constriction of the renal artery or aorta
  • Various psychological stimuli

Inhibitory

  • Increased Na+ and Cl- reabsorption across macula densa
  • Increased afferent arteriolar pressure
  • Angiotensin II
  • ADH (vasopressin)

questions.text: Which among the following tyrosine kinase inhibitors can be used for the treatment of polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
Ruxolitinib is approved by the FDA for the treatment of myelofibrosis and polycythemia vera.

Other options:

  • Tofacitinib and Baricitinib are used for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Fostamatinib is a spleen tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of chronic immune thrombocytopenia.
  • Sunitinib is used in the treatment of GIST, PNET, and RCC
  • Imatinib, Nilotinib, Dasatinib, and Ponatinib is used in the treatment of CML

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about lipofuscin?

choices.text: It is injurious to the cell

questions.solution:
Lipofuscin is not injurious to the cell or its functions.

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • An insoluble pigment, also known as lipochrome or wear-and-tear pigment.
  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes.
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions.
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • Appears as a yellow-brown pigment in tissue sections.
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes.
  • Prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

questions.text: All of the following are part of the organ of Corti except:
questions.solution: Otoliths are crystal bodies consisting mostly of calcium carbonate. They are components of the otolithic membrane of the maculae of the utricle and saccule. (not organ of Corti)

questions.text: Dysplastic cells covering the full thickness of the cervical epithelium with an intact basement membrane falls under which category of the Bethesda cytological grading system?
questions.solution:
Dysplastic cells covering the full thickness of the cervical epithelium with intact basement membrane is classified as high-grade squamous intra-epithelial lesion in the Bethesda system of grading.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: A 28-year-old female known case of bronchial asthma on low dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) presents to you with increased bouts of breathlessness. Her method of using the inhaler is correct and the exposure to allergens are minimal to none. While deciding to step up her therapy which is the appropriate regimen for this patient?

choices.text: Formoterol along with low dose ICS
Salmeterol along with high dose ICS

questions.solution:
The patient during presentation, was on treatment with low dose ICS (Step 2, according to the NAEPP (National Asthma Education and Prevention Program, Expert Panel Report 3)).

The preferred step up (Step 3) therapy in the above patient would mean:

  • Starting her on Medium-dose ICS, or
  • Keeping her on low-dose ICS with an additional LABA (like formoterol/salmeterol)

Alternatively: she can be kept on low-dose ICS with either LTRA, theophylline, or zileuton.

Note: Formoterol and salmeterol have a bronchodilator action of more than 12 hours and are usually administered twice daily.

Short-acting Beta Agonists (SABA):

  • Albuterol
  • Levalbuterol
  • Pirbuterol
  • Terbutaline

Long-acting Beta Agonists (LABA):

  • Salmeterol
  • Formoterol
  • Arformoterol

Ultra-Long-acting Beta Agonists (uLABA):

  • Indacaterol
  • Olodaterol
  • Vilanterol

questions.text: The fracture seen in the image given below is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows an extra-articular fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal which is known as Jones fracture.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the lower limb

Fracture Location
Hoffa fracture Coronal fracture of femoral condyles
Bumper fracture Comminuted fracture of lateral condyle of tibia 
Pilon fracture Comminuted intra-articular fracture of the distal end of the tibia 
Tillaux fracture Avulsion fracture of the tibia by the anterior tibiofibular ligament
Runner's fracture Fracture of the distal shaft of fibula 
Pott’s fracture Bimalleolar ankle fracture
Cotton’s fracture Trimalleolar ankle fracture
Aviator's fracture Fracture of neck of talus
Chopart’s fracture Fracture between talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints 
Lisfranc’s fracture-dislocation Fracture of metatarsal bases with associated tarsometatarsal dislocation

Jone's fracture

Extra-articular fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal
Dancer’s fracture Fracture of distal shaft of the fifth metatarsal

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Jackson’s double-lumen metal tracheostomy tube.

It has an outer tube, an inner tube, and an obturator (not shown in the image). The outer tube is not split, the inner tube can be fixed to the shield of the outer tube by a lock.

Other options:

  • Cuffed tracheostomy tube:
  • Fuller’s tracheostomy tube: Inner and outer tubes:

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A fracture at the neck of the fifth metacarpal is known as:
questions.solution:
A fracture at the neck of the fifth metacarpal is known as boxer's fracture. It results from punching an object with a closed fist.

Given below is an x-ray showing boxer’s fracture:

Other options:

  • Bennett’s fracture-dislocation- occurs at the base of the first metacarpal bone and is commonly due to punching.
  • Ronaldo’s fracture- intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.
  • March fracture- stress fracture of the second metatarsal.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: Which among the following brain tumors has the worst long-term prognosis?
questions.solution:
Glioblastoma multiforme (Grade IV) has the worst long-term prognosis (median survival of roughly 1 year).

Other options:

In the case of anaplastic astrocytoma (Grade III),  survival is 2 to 3 years. In pilocytic astrocytomas (Grade I), survival is 8 years.

Subependymomas are uncommon, benign (Grade 1) tumors, which are slow growing and non-invasive.

Astrocytomas (Graded I to IV) are the most common primary CNS neoplasm. The term often is used to refer to astrocytomas specifically, excluding other glial tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Proprioception is a function of the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei: 3 sensory (mesencephalic, spinal, and principal sensory nucleus) and 1 motor.

NUCLEUS LOCATION FUNCTION
Mesencephalic nucleus Composed of a column of unipolar nerve cells situated in the midbrain and extends inferiorly into the pons as far as the main sensory nucleus. Receives the sensation of proprioception from the muscles of mastication and from the facial and extraocular muscles.
Main Sensory nucleus Posterior part of the pons lateral to the motor nucleus. Receives the sensations of touch and pressure from the face.
Spinal Nucleus Continuous superiorly with the main sensory nucleus and extends inferiorly the whole of the medulla oblongata and reaches as far as the 2nd Cervical Segment. Receives the sensation of pain and temperature from the face and some fibers of touch.
Motor nucleus The pons medial to the main sensory nucleus. Supplies the muscles of mastication, the tensor tympani, the tensor veli palitini and the mylohyoid and the anterior belly of digastric muscle.

questions.text: The selective medium used to isolate Bacillus anthracis is_______
questions.solution:
PLET medium is used to isolate Bacillus anthracis.

It is a selective medium consisting of polymyxin, lysozyme, ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA), and thallous acetate added to heart infusion agar.

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man working in a factory for the past 30 years, presents with dyspnea and cough due to chronic exposure to a particular mineral agent. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows characteristic golden brown bodies with beaded and knobbed ends. All of the following are caused by exposure to this agent, except  ______.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with histopathology showing golden-brown asbestos bodies with knobbed or beaded ends is due to asbestos exposure. All of the given conditions are caused by exposure to asbestos except anthracosis. Anthracosis is a coal-induced pulmonary lesion.

Asbestosis is a diffuse interstitial fibrosing disease of the lung that occurs due to asbestos exposure. The disease usually manifests after a minimum of 10 years of exposure. Asbestos-related diseases include:

  • Localized fibrous plaques or diffuse pleural fibrosis
  • Recurrent pleural effusions
  • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis 
  • Lung carcinoma
  • Mesotheliomas
  • Laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas

Clinically, dyspnea and cough are seen. They can progress to respiratory failure, cor pulmonale, and even death. Chest radiograph can show irregular linear densities in lower lobes and in late stages can show a honey-combed pattern.

Histopathology shows diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and asbestos bodies. These appear as golden brown fusiform or rod-shaped beaded structures with a translucent center that is made of asbestos fibers coated by a proteinaceous material. They arise when asbestos gets phagocytosed by macrophages. Iron-protein complexes may coat other inorganic particulate matter to form ferruginous bodies.

The below image shows asbestos bodies.

 

Anthracosis is commonly seen in coal miners, urban dwellers, and tobacco smokers. It is caused by chronic exposure to coal dust. Wheeze is a typical finding seen in anthracosis. They can present with cough and, dyspnoea as well. Black carbon deposits in the lungs may be visible grossly as well as microscopically.

questions.text: Which of the following  is not true about autophagy?

choices.text: Microautophagy is the major form of autophagy
LC3  is a useful marker for autophagy

questions.solution:
Microautophagy is not the major form of autophagy. Macroautophagy is the major form.

Autophagy is a process in which a cell eats its own contents.

It involves the delivery of cytoplasmic materials to the lysosome for degradation. Depending on how the material is delivered, autophagy can be categorized into three types:

  • Chaperone-mediated autophagy- direct translocation across the lysosomal membrane by chaperone proteins
  • Microautophagy- inward invagination of lysosomal membrane for delivery
  • Macroautophagy- the major form of autophagy involving the sequestration and transportation of portions of cytosol in a double membrane-bound autophagic vacuole (autophagosome)

Other options:

The synthesis of LC3 (microtubule-associated protein light chain 3) is augmented during autophagy and it is therefore a useful marker for autophagy.

Autophagy functions as a survival mechanism under various stress conditions, it is therefore prominent in atrophic cells.

Role of autophagy in human diseases:

  • Cancer:  autophagy can both promote cancer growth and act as a defense against cancers.
  • Neurodegenerative disorders: Many neurodegenerative disorders are associated with dysregulation of autophagy e.g Alzheimer disease- accelerated autophagy; Huntington disease- impaired autophagy.
  • Infectious diseases: Many pathogens are degraded by autophagy e.g. mycobacteria, Shigella, HSV-1.
  • Inflammatory bowel diseases: Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis have been linked to mutations in autophagy-related genes.

questions.text: In Echinococcus granulosis infection, human acts as:
questions.solution:
Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end) in Echinococcus granulosis.

Echinococcus granulosus is also known as dog tapeworm.

The worm completes its life cycle in 2 hosts:

  • Definitive host: Dog, wolf, jackal, fox
  • Intermediate host: Sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel

Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors is deficient in serum?
questions.solution:
Serum is similar to plasma except that clotting factors I (Fibrinogen), II (Prothrombin), V (Proaccelerin) and VIII (Anti-haemophilic factor) are deficient in serum. It is formed when whole blood is allowed to clot and the clot is removed.

Serum also has a high serotonin content because of platelet breakdown during clotting.

questions.text: A patient who is posted for renal transplant in 5 hours is started on an interleukin- 2 receptor antagonist to prevent acute transplant rejection. Which of the following drugs would have likely been given?
questions.solution:
Basiliximab is the interleukin-2 receptor antagonist that would have been likely given.

It is otherwise known as the anti-CD25 antibody and is a murine-human chimeric monoclonal antibody that acts by inhibiting T-cell activation and proliferation, but does not induce cell lysis. It is used prophylactically to prevent acute solid-organ rejection. 

Basiliximab is used with a maintenance regimen consisting of cyclosporine and prednisone. It is also effectively used in a maintenance regimen consisting of cyclosporine, Mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Lymphoproliferative disorders and anaphylactic reactions may occur rarely as adverse effects.

Other options:

Option A: Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and arrests the immune response at a later stage than cyclosporine. It can be used alone or in combination with cyclosporine or corticosteroid and mycophenolate mofetil. It is not recommended for a liver transplant. 

Option C: Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor and is highly effective in preventing graft rejection reactions. However, it is nephrotoxic.

Option D: Alemtuzumab is a humanized IgG1 that binds to CD52 found on normal and malignant B and T lymphocytes, NK cells, monocytes, macrophages, and a small population of granulocytes. It is used for the treatment of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia, relapsing and remitting multiple sclerosis and as an off-label in kidney transplant.

questions.text: Elimination of disease in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts can be referred to as:
questions.solution:
Elimination of a disease refers to zero incidence of a disease.

  • Elimination: Reduction to zero (or a very low defined target rate) of new cases of an infectious disease in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts; continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.
  • Eradication: Complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts; no further control measures are required.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the tympanogram shown below is true?

choices.text: Normal compliance and a negative pressure

questions.solution:
The tympanogram shown suggests that the tympanic cavity has increased compliance and the intratympanic pressure is normal. It is a type AD curve.

The differential diagnosis for the above tympanogram is:

  • Ossicular discontinuity
  • Thin/lax tympanic membrane

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: Paragonimus westermani infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab containing:
questions.solution:
Paragonimus westermani infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab containing metacercariae.

Paragonimus westermani:

  • The metacercariae excyst in the human gut
  • Young worms migrate to the lungs and become encapsulated
  • Eggs released by the adult worms move up to the pharynx, are swallowed and passed in the feces
  • Adult lung flukes appear as grayish-white nodules approximately 1 cm in size within the lung
  • This causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis

questions.text: 40-year-old presents with intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea on and off for about 1 year. An upper GI endoscopy showed multiple duodenal ulcers. An MRI revealed a tumor in the pancreas and the serum gastrin level is measured to be 1.1 ng/mL. There was no evidence of metastatic lesions. What is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the patient is Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Proton-pump inhibitors (like Pantoprazole) are the drug of choice in Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. It is usually given at twice the routine dosage for peptic ulcers.

Zollinger Ellison syndrome:

  • Pancreatic or duodenal gastrinomas lead to the secretion of large amounts of gastric acid giving rise to multiple severe gastroduodenal ulcers.
  • PPIs are superior to H2 blockers in reducing gastric acid secretion.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: What is the most common aneuploidy associated with a diagnosis of cystic hygroma in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
About 70 percent of cystic hygromas are associated with aneuploidy, and trisomy 21 or Down syndrome is the most common aneuploidy associated with a diagnosis in the first trimester.

When cystic hygroma is apparent only in the second trimester, Turner syndrome is the most likely cause.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about port wine stain:
questions.solution:
Features of port wine stain:

  • Does not fade with time
  • Special form of nevus flammeus
  • Tend to grow during childhood
  • Thicken the skin surface

Port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve is associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Given below is an image of port-wine stain:

questions.text: Which of the following is true about metropathia haemorrhagica?

choices.text: It is seen in ovulatory cycles

questions.solution:
Metropathia hemorrhagica is a specialized form of anovulatory dysfunctional uterine bleeding, and since there is no ovulation, the corpus luteum and secretory endometrium are absent. Endometrial glandular hyperplasia with projection of polyps into the uterine cavity is seen along with a mild degree of myometrial hyperplasia.

Typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses, or preceded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhea. Occasionally, the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

questions.text: Which of the following is termed as a compound presentation?

choices.text: Passage of fetal head and thorax through pelvic cavity at the same time
Presentation of one breech and one head in twin pregnancies
Presentation of an arm alongside the fetal head
Impaction of shoulder in shoulder presentation

questions.solution:
Compound presentation is defined as an extremity prolapsing alongside the presenting part. Contracted pelvis, fetal prematurity, polyhydramnios, and multi-fetal gestations predispose to this presentation.

The most common compound presentation is a hand prolapsing alongside the head. In most cases, expectant management is enough. With the progression of labor, the prolapsed hand retracts with the descent of the fetal head. If retraction fails and the hand seems to be blocking the head, the prolapsed arm is gently pushed upward and fundal pressure is applied to promote descent of the head.

If cord prolapse is present or the pelvis is contracted, Caesarean section should be done.

questions.text: Neurovascular bundle of anterior compartment of the leg contains _______
questions.solution:
Neurovascular bundle of anterior compartment of the leg contains deep fibular nerve.

Neurovascular components in various compartments of leg are as follows: 

  • Anterior compartment: Anterior tibial artery and Deep fibular/peroneal nerve
  • Posterior deep compartment: Tibial nerve and posterior tibial vessels in the deep plane.
  • Lateral Compartment: Superficial peroneal/fibular nerve and peroneal/fibular vessel. Peroneal artery is a branch of posterior tibial artery.

Note: MRI is the best imaging modality for evaluating the soft tissues of the leg.

questions.text: Which of the following bulges out in keratocele?
questions.solution:
In keratocele, the layer that bulges out is the Descemet’s membrane. Hence, it’s also called Descemetocele. It happens when the overlying layers are eroded by inflammatory processes secondary to infection. The Descemet’s membrane is resistant to inflammation and bulges out due to the intra-ocular pressure.

The bulging membrane may persist surrounded by a white cicatricial ring or may rupture.

questions.text: Among the given spinal anaesthetic agents, addition of epinephrine causes maximum prolongation of duration in:
questions.solution:
Epinephrine can prolong the duration of tetracaine by more than 50%.

There is only a modest increase in duration of action of bupivacaine, lidocaine and procaine by the addition of epinephrine.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about the fungus shown in the image given below:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Aspergillus niger. Aspergillus grows as a fungal ball within pre-existing lung cavity known as aspergilloma.

Aspergillus:

  • It is an opportunistic mycosis
  • It has septate hyphae
  • It is a filamentous fungus, not dimorphic

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A patient developed painless purple reticular discoloration of the legs. On enquiry, he reports taking drugs for parkinsonism. Identify the drug responsible:
questions.solution:
Amantadine causes dilation of blood vessels which results in the appearance of non-blanching purplish dermal streaks called livedo reticularis.

It has been reported in up to 5 percent of persons taking the drug for more than a month. The discolouration diminishes on elevating the legs and disappears after the patient stops taking the drug.

Livedo reticularis:

questions.text: Features of tumour lysis syndrome are all except:
questions.solution:
Tumour lysis syndrome does not include hypercalcemia.

Tumour lysis syndrome occurs during the destruction of malignancies. During the destruction of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells, the release of intracellular electrolytes causes the following effects:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Dehydration

questions.text: Which food item among the options given has the lowest net protein utilization value?
questions.solution:
The net protein utilization value of the food items given in decreasing order is:

Cow milk (81) > Meat (79) > Rice (65) > Soya (55)

If the NPU is low, the protein requirement is high.

The NPU of protein in Indian diets is between 50 and 80.

Related Pearl: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

  • Amino acid score:
  • Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.

 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:

B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 

Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about antigen-antibody reactions:

choices.text: Avidity is the closeness of fit between epitope and paratope
The agglutinate is composed of denatured antigens
Specific fragments of the molecules participate in the reaction

questions.solution:
The antigen antibody combination is reversible.

The bond depends on affinity and avidity of the reaction:

  • Affinity- Intensity of attraction between the antigen and antibody. It depends on the closeness of fit between epitope and paratope (antigen binding region of the antibody).
  • Avidity- strength of the bond of the antigen-antibody complexes. It is a better measure of binding capacity within biological systems.

Other features of antigen-antibody reactions:

  • Specificity: antigen combines only with its homologous antibody and vice versa, except- cross reactions with similar antigens
  • Molecules are involved in the reaction as a whole and not as specific fragments, i.e. whole of molecules are agglutinated.
  • There is no denaturation of the antigen or the antibody
  • The agglutinate/precipitate is composed of both antigens and antibodies

questions.text: Which of the following is not a property of orthomyxoviruses?
questions.solution:
Orthomyxoviruses have single stranded RNA.

Properties of Orthomyxoviruses:

  • Virion: Spherical, pleomorphic, 80–120 nm in diameter (helical nucleocapsid, 9 nm)
  • Genome: Single-stranded negative-sense RNA, segmented (eight molecules)
  • Envelope: Contains viral hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins
  • High frequency of genetic reassortment lead to antigenic changes in the viral surface glycoproteins making the infection difficult to control.e.g. Influenza type A is antigenically highly variable and is responsible for most cases of epidemic influenza.

questions.text: Identify the tumour that is correctly matched with its primary location:
questions.solution:
Chondroblastoma is a benign tumour of immature cartilage cells that appears primarily in the epiphysis.

Other options:

  • Chondrosarcoma- common malignant tumor usually appearing in the metaphysis of long bones.
  • Enchondroma/chondroma- benign tumor arising from islands of cartilage in the metaphyses of bones formed by endochondral ossification.
  • Osteosarcoma- highly malignant tumour commonly involving the metaphysis of long bones.

Related Pearl: Most common sites of primary bone tumors

EPIPHYSEAL :

  • Chondroblastoma 
  • Giant cell tumor in adults
  • Articular osteochondroma (trevor’s disease)
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma 

DIAPHYSEAL:

  • Round cell lesions-Ewing’s sarcoma 
  • Lymphoma
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Adamantinoma
  • Osteoid osteoma
  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Histiocytosis
  • Osteoblastoma

METAPHYSEAL:

  • Chondrosarcoma (Note:Clear cell chondrosarcoma is epiphyseal)
  • Enchondroma
  • Osteochondroma
  • Bone cyst
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Giant cell tumor in children

questions.text: Which of the following medications is a reversible inhibitor of MAO?
questions.solution:
Safinamide is a reversible and selective MAO-B inhibitor used for the treatment of on & off phenomenon.

Phenelzine, isocarboxazid, and tranylcypromine are non-selective irreversible MAO inhibitors.

Selegiline and rasagiline are irreversible selective MAO-B inhibitors.

questions.text: Under the National Health Mission, an Urban Community Health Centre for a non-metropolitan city caters to a population of _____________.
questions.solution:
An urban CHC caters to a population of 5 lakh in a metropolitan city and 2.5 lakh in other cities.

An urban PHC caters to a population of 50,000.

questions.text: Haddon matrix is related to ______.
questions.solution:
The Haddon Matrix is a paradigm used in the research on injury prevention and intervention, developed by William Haddon.

Matrix looks at factors related to personal attributes, vector or agent attributes, and environmental attributes, before, during, and after an injury or death.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied up in a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a diatom. Postmortem drowning does not show diatoms in the brain tissue.

Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

The presence of diatoms in the brain tissue is suggestive of antemortem drowning, as only a living person can transport diatoms from the lungs to the viscera via circulation.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning
Froth/ foam at nostrils or mouth Present Absent
Cadaveric spasm Present Absent
Lungs

Edema aquosum(seen in unconscious) 

Lungs are voluminous, bulky, water-logged and over-inflated

 

Passive collection of water in the lungs

Demonstration of diatoms  Present in the lungs, liver, brain, bone marrow, etc.

Present only in the lungs

Not spread to distant organs because of absence of circulation
Stomach contents 

Water

Foreign material like sand, weed, dirt etc  (swallowed while struggling for life)

Water (lesser quantity)

questions.text: Given below are substances matched with potential consequences of chronic abuse. Identify the wrong match.
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) does not produce physical dependence.

Other substances of abuse that do not produce physical dependence include cocaine, cannabis, and amphetamines. The potential consequences of chronic abuse of LSD are flashbacks or bad trips. 

Physical dependence: Frequent exposure to the drug leads to an altered neurophysiological state. This is characterized by the emergence of tolerance to the drug as well as withdrawal symptoms when the chronically abused drug is discontinued.

Other options:

Option A: Korsakoff syndrome is seen with chronic alcohol abuse. It is characterized by anterograde and retrograde amnesia, disorientation, and confabulation (describing fabricated experiences to fill gaps in memory).

Option B: Amotivational syndrome is seen with chronic cannabis abuse. It is characterized by lethargy and reduced interest in day-to-day activities. 

Option D: Tactile hallucinations seen with cocaine abuse. The affected individual percieves small insects creeping on the skin, giving rise to itching sensations. These hallucinations are termed cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptoms.

Related Pearl: Specific effects of substance abuse

Substance

Associations
Cocaine

Magnan syndrome (cocaine bugs or tactile hallucinations)

Mini packers syndrome
Phencyclidine Dissociative anaesthesia (Angel dust)
LSD Bad trips, Flashbacks
Amphetamine Paranoid hallucinatory syndrome
Alcohol  Mc Ewan’s sign, Morbid jealousy
Cannabis Amotivational syndrome, Run amok

questions.text: Identify the primary deformity in clubfoot complex:
questions.solution: Forefoot adduction is a primary deformity in clubfoot complex.

questions.text: The effect of abnormal pseudocholinesterase enzyme on the action of succinylcholine is:
questions.solution:
Abnormal pseudocholinesterase enzyme prolongs the duration of action of succinylcholine.

Succinylcholine is rapidly metabolised by pseudocholinesterase as soon as it enters the circulation. This results in the short duration of action of succinylcholine.

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase, resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defect, cannot metabolise succinylcholine efficiently, leading to prolonged duration of action.

The rapid onset of action of succinylcholine is because of its small volume of distribution resulting from very low lipid solubility.

questions.text:
Mycobacterium leprae is grown in:
(i) Footpads of mice, (ii) Armadillo, (iii) Tissue culture, (iv) Fertile eggs
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium leprae is grown by inoculating bacilli from human leprosy into the footpads of mice or into the armadillos:

  • Inoculated footpads of mice- local granulomatous lesions develop with limited multiplication of bacilli
  • Inoculated armadillos- develop extensive lepromatous leprosy

M. leprae cannot be cultivated in vitro.

questions.text: Positive hepatojugular reflux is present in all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Cardiac tamponade is the only condition among the options provided that does not show a positive abdominojugular/hepatojugular reflux (HJR).

A positive HJR is defined by an increase in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) > 3 cm, sustained for greater than 15 seconds on applying gentle pressure over the right upper quadrant (over the liver) or mid-abdomen.

It signifies that the right ventricle cannot accommodate the augmented venous return.

It is commonly evident, in right ventricular failure and in left ventricular failure with a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) greater than 15 mmHg.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease of bone
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is associated with the Marchiafava Bignami disease?
questions.solution:
Marchiafava Bignami Disease (MBD) is an idiopathic syndrome of dementia and seizures seen in chronic alcoholics. It is associated with central degeneration of corpus callosum, sparing the dorsal and ventral parts. This characteristic pattern of degeneration presents as sandwich sign, best visualized on sagittal MRI of the brain.

There are 2 clinical subtypes of MBD:

  • Type A - Severe form characterized by coma and stupor. There is marked callosal necrosis
  • Type B - Milder form characterised by mildly impaired mental status and focal callosal lesions

questions.text: Which one of the following is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision used in abdominal surgeries?
questions.solution:
Chevron (rooftop) incision is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision, which provides excellent access to the upper abdomen for total gastrectomy, operations for renovascular hypertension, total esophagectomy, liver transplantation, extensive hepatic resections, bilateral adrenalectomy, etc.

Lanz incision is an oblique muscle splitting incision used for appendectomy. It is cosmetically better than the Mcburney’s Gridiron incision.

Rutherford-Morrison’s incision is an oblique muscle cutting incision, with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally, as necessary.

Kocher’s incision is used for open cholecystectomy.

Pfannenstiel incision is not a muscle cutting incision. Rectus abdominis muscle is not attached to the posterior sheath below the umbilicus, and following separation from the anterior sheath, the muscle is retracted laterally.

questions.text: What is the anterior most structure that can be visualised by the technique shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows indirect ophthalmoscopy being performed and the anterior most structure that can be visualised using this technique is the ora serrata.

questions.text: A patient walks with a stomping gait. When asked to close his eyes and walk, he is unable to do so. Which of the following tracts is probably affected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the involvement of the posterior column.

Posterior column carries proprioception which is essential for coordination of motor movements. Loss of this leads to the development of a stomping gait. This is seen in cases of vitamin B12 deficiency leading to subacute combined degeneration, tabes dorsalis or diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: A nurse comes to you for advice regarding the disposal of a broken ampoule. Which of the following containers would you advise her to use?
questions.solution:
Broken or discarded and contaminated glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, should be disposed off in blue containers.

questions.text: Which of the following medications cannot be used to treat pulmonary infection caused by Eaton’s agent in an adult?
questions.solution:
Ceftazidime (a third-generation antipseudomonal cephalosporin) cannot be used to treat an infection caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae (Eaton’s agent).

Mycoplasmas lack a cell wall and are bound only by a cell membrane. Thus, they are inherently resistant to all cell-wall synthesis inhibitors (β lactam antibiotics: penicillin and cephalosporins).

questions.text: The most common complication in patients of bariatric surgery is _______
questions.solution:
Anastomotic leak is the most common complication in patients of bariatric surgery.

Most common cause of death in bariatric surgery: DVT/Pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Clergyman’s knee refers to the inflammation of:
questions.solution:
The inflammation of infrapatellar bursa is referred to as Clergyman’s knee.

The swelling is below the patella and superficial to the patellar ligament.

The treatment consists of firm bandaging, rest, aspiration or excision if needed.

Related Pearl: Bursitis

questions.text: Monoclonal antibody shown to be useful for Crohn’s disease is:
questions.solution:
Natalizumab is a recombinant humanized IgG4 antibody against α4-integrin that has been shown to be effective in the induction and maintenance of patients with Crohn’s disease.

Other options:

  • Omalizumab: Anti-IgE monoclonal antibody, used in the treatment of bronchial asthma, urticaria.
  • Palivizumab: It is a monoclonal antibody that can be used for passive protection with immunotherapy in patients infected by the respiratory syncytial virus (RSV).
  • Trastuzumab: It is a monoclonal antibody that is used in the treatment of HER2neu receptor-positive breast cancer.

questions.text: The Emsley-Fincham test is performed in a patient who complains of blurred vision and seeing colored halos. The patient reports breaking up of the halo into rotating segments. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Breaking up of coloured halos into rotating segments on performing the Emsley-Fincham test with a stenopaeic slit indicates cataract.

Related Pearl: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo

The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: Which of the following condition shows linear pattern of deposits on immunofluorescent study of the glomerular basement membrane?
questions.solution:
Goodpasture syndrome cases show linear GBM fluorescence for Ig and complement.

Immunofluorescence study of other conditions:

  • Postinfectious Glomerulonephritis- granular deposits
  • Membranous nephropathy- granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement
  • Minimal change disease- No Ig or complement deposits.

questions.text: Which of the following non-biological drugs is a DMARD?
questions.solution:
Minocycline, a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor, and a tetracycline antibiotic is a non-biological disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid agent (DMARD).

Other options:

Cetuximab: It is a recombinant, chimeric human/mouse IgG1 antibody that binds to EGFR and prevents ligand-dependent signaling and receptor dimerization, thereby blocking cell growth and survival signals. It is used to treat patients with metastatic colon cancers and head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). It is also the first-line treatment for Menetrier’s disease.

Rituximab: Rituximab is an anti CD20 monoclonal antibody that is a biological DMARD.

Daptomycin: It is a cyclic lipopeptide antibiotic.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: The toxicity of endotoxin is attributed to:
questions.solution:
The toxicity of endotoxin is attributed to Lipid A.

Endotoxin- Lipopolysaccharide(LPS) of gram-negative cell walls is known as endotoxin. LPS is made of Lipid A and polysaccharide. Lipid A is responsible for toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a treatment modality in the management of an ovarian pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ovarian pregnancies are managed surgically. Small lesions are managed by ovarian cystectomy or wedge resection. Beta hCG levels are then monitored to exclude the possibility of remnant trophoblast.

With larger lesions, oophorectomy is done.

questions.text: Which of the following is a kinin receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioneurotic edema?
questions.solution:
Icatibant is a selective Bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist that is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioneurotic edema.

Other options:

  • Ecallantide is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is administered subcutaneously.
  • Aprotinin is a natural proteinase inhibitor that was tried in reducing the inflammation during cardiopulmonary bypass surgery.
  • Aprepitant is a neurokinin receptor antagonist that is used treatment of cytotoxic (chemotherapy) drug-induced vomiting.

questions.text: How does the Jendrassik manoeuvre reinforce the knee jerk reflex?

choices.text: Activates group 1b nerve fibres in tendon
Decreases activity of group 1a nerve fibres

questions.solution:
Jendrassik's maneuver reinforces the knee-jerk reflex by increasing the gamma motor neuron discharge from the spinal cord. Increased gamma motor discharge increases the sensitivity of group 1a nerve fibers in the muscle spindles to stretch. Increased activity of the group 1a afferents enhances deep tendon reflexes, including the knee jerk reflex.

The maneuver can also enhance reflexes by distracting the subject and preventing conscious inhibition.

Other options:

Group 1b fibres in the Golgi tendon organ are activated in the inverse stretch reflex.

questions.text: The image given below shows a muscle tension-length relationship graph. Identify the factor responsible for the downslope marked in the graph with the number 3:
questions.solution:
The reduced tension generated by a muscle with stretched sarcomeres is due to a reduction in the number of actin-myosin cross bridges.

The length of the muscle at which maximum tension is generated is called the optimal resting length of the muscle.

At muscle lengths below the optimal length, the distance over which the thin actin filaments can move is reduced and hence generated tension is low.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with thyroid swelling. She was previously treated with radiation therapy for Hodgkin's lymphoma. She has no fever or night sweats. What do you suspect this patient is likely to be diagnosed with?
questions.solution:
This patient with a thyroid swelling, who was treated for Hodgkin’s lymphoma (by radiation), is likely to have papillary thyroid cancer.

Radiation is the only established risk factor for the development of differentiated thyroid carcinoma (papillary and follicular). This association is stronger for papillary than for follicular carcinomas.

The risk of developing papillary thyroid cancer is high among individuals who

  • Received external irradiation to the thyroid as children (<5 years of age)
  • Received radiation for soft tissue malignancies, such as Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Have a history of acute environmental exposure

Note:

Risk factor for the development of thyroid lymphoma is non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (and not Hodgkin’s). Moreover, the absence of B-symptoms (fever, night sweats, and weight loss) makes the diagnosis of thyroid lymphoma unlikely.

Chernobyl disaster: The incidence of childhood thyroid cancer (specifically papillary) rose up to 100 times as compared to before the incident.

questions.text: Which of the following technique is used to sequence proteins without prior purification?
questions.solution:
Tandem mass spectrometry can be used to sequence proteins without prior purification.

Tandem mass spectrometry involves two mass spectrometers linked in series. Individual peptides are separated by the first spectrometer based on the differences in mass of each peptide.

A single peptide is directed to the second mass spectrometer by adjusting the field strength of the first magnet. Here, it gets fragmented and the mass is determined.

It is used to screen the blood samples of newborns for genetic disorders such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutamic acidemia.

Other options:

Ion exchange chromatography, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, and isoelectric focusing are the methods of purifying/separating proteins.

Related Pearl: Some Important Methods Used to Study Glycoproteins

Method Use
Periodic acid-Schiff stain Detects glycoprotein as pink bands
Mass spectrometry Molecular mass, composition, sequence, and sometimes branching of a glycan chain. can be used for site-specific glycosylation profiling.
NMR spectroscopy To identify specific sugars, their sequence, linkages, and the anomeric nature of glycosidic chain.
Amino acid or cDNA sequencing Determination of amino acid sequence.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a predisposing condition for brain abscess?
questions.solution:
Left-to-right shunt does not predispose to brain abscess. Congenital heart diseases with Right-to-left shunts predispose to brain abscess because there is loss of pulmonary filtration of organisms.

Brain Abscess:

A brain abscess is a localized focus of necrosis of brain tissue with accompanying inflammation, usually caused by a bacterial infection.

Brain abscesses may arise by:

  • Direct implantation of organisms
  • Local extension from adjacent foci- mastoiditis, paranasal sinusitis
  • Hematogenous spread- from a primary site in the heart, lungs, bones, or after tooth extraction.

Predisposing conditions include:

  • Acute bacterial endocarditis
  • Congenital heart disease with right-to-left shunting
  • Chronic pulmonary sepsis, as in bronchiectasis
  • Systemic disease with immunosuppression

questions.text: Which of the following muscles elevates the ribs?
questions.solution:
Levatores costarum elevates the ribs.

The muscles of inspiration help increase the diameters of the thoracic cavity by elevating the ribs.

The muscles of expiration help in depression of the ribs. The serratus posterior inferior is an accessory muscle of expiration.

Mnemonic: SIT-Q depressors that work along with anterior abdominals for expiration:

  • Serratus posterior inferior
  • Internal intercostals
  • Transversus thoracis
  • Quadratus lumborum

questions.text: Ascorbic acid is involved in which of the following group of reactions?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C or ascorbic acid is involved in oxidation-reduction reactions. It acts as a coenzyme of the following enzymes.

  • Lysyl and prolyl hydroxylase: in the post-translational modification of procollagen to collagen
  • 7-α-hydroxylase: in the conversion of cholesterol to bile acids
  • Dopamine-β-hydroxylase: in catecholamine synthesis
  • Trimethyl lysine hydroxylase: in carnitine biosynthesis
  • Reduction of ferric to ferrous iron: it enhances the absorption of non-heme iron from the intestine.

questions.text: Which phase of damage control surgery focuses on definitive surgery?
questions.solution:
Phase 3 of damage control surgery focuses on definitive surgery.

Damage control surgery:

  • It centers on coordinating staged, operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.
  • It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen in an eﬀort to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive hemorrhage.
  • 3 Phases:
    • Phase I (Initial Exploration): This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination.
    • Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation): This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy, and acidosis.
    • Phase III (Definitive Operation): It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of type 1 respiratory failure?
questions.solution:
Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology is the mechanism involved in the pathogenesis of type 1 (acute hypoxemic) respiratory failure.

Alveolar flooding can be due to: pulmonary edema, lung injury, pneumonia, or alveolar hemorrhage.

questions.text: Paradoxical incontinence is seen in:
questions.solution:
Paradoxical incontinence occurs in an ectopic ureter.

In females, an ectopic ureter opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina. A woman who voids normally but who has dribbled urine for as long as she can remember, probably has an ectopic ureteral orifice. This is paradoxical incontinence.

questions.text: A patient with lepromatous leprosy presents with eye pain. The image of his eye is given below. Identify the finding marked by the arrow:
questions.solution:
The finding marked by the arrow in the image of the eye of a patient with lepromatous leprosy is the iris pearl, which is a pathognomonic finding of leprosy.

Leprosy or Hansen disease is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae. Ocular features in leprosy occur due to bacterial invasion. They include the following:

  • Keratitis with thickened, beaded corneal nerves, punctate subepithelial lesions, pannus, and vascularization
  • Chronic low-grade anterior uveitis
  • Miosis
  • Iris atrophy
  • Iris pearls 
  • Retinal pearls
  • Other features are scleritis, episcleritis, cataracts, diminished corneal sensation, etc. 

Other options:

Option A: Brushfield spots refer to small white speckles on the peripheral iris that are arranged in a concentric ring. They are seen in Down’s syndrome and may sometimes be a normal finding in blue eyes. The image below shows Brushfield spots.

Option C: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Option D: Busacca nodules are present on the iris stroma. They are seen in granulomatous uveitis.

The image below shows Koeppe nodules. These are present at the pupillary border and are seen in anterior uveitis.

questions.text: Identify the following suture material:
questions.solution:
The image is of vicryl or polyglactin, which is a braided multifilament absorbable suture. It is a copolymer of lactide and glycolide in a ratio of 90:10, coated with polyglactin and calcium stearate.

Absorption is by hydrolysis. Complete absorption occurs in 60–90 days.

It is used mostly for gut anastomosis, vascular ligatures, subcuticular wound closures, and ophthalmic surgeries.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of adrenaline would be blocked by phentolamine but not propranolol?
questions.solution: The contraction of dilator pupillae is mediated by α1 adrenergic receptors. Thus, propranolol has no inhibitory action on this effect of adrenaline. All the other options are mediated by β receptors which can be blocked by propranolol.

questions.text: Which among the following features is most suggestive of extravascular hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Splenomegaly is a feature of extravascular hemolysis.

Extravascular hemolysis: Red cell destruction occurs within phagocytes especially in the spleen. Persistent extravascular hemolysis leads to hyperplasia of phagocytes manifested by splenomegaly. The principal clinical features of extravascular hemolysis are:

  • Anemia
  • Splenomegaly
  • Jaundice

Intravascular hemolysis: Red cell destruction occurs within the blood vessels/circulation. It is caused by mechanical injury, complement fixation, intracellular parasites or exogenous toxic factors.

Large amounts of free hemoglobin released from lysed red cells leading to:

  • Hemoglobinemia, hemoglobinuria, hemosiderinuria
  • Methemoglobin- due to oxidation of free hemoglobin
  • Renal hemosiderosis- due to accumulation of iron released from hemoglobin within the tubular cells.

questions.text: A young patient with Hepatitis E virus infection develops acute liver failure. Which of the following scores can be used in assessing the prognosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with acute liver failure, MELD score and King's College Hospital criteria can be used to assess the prognosis.

Option A: Pitt score is used used to predict mortality in patients having bloodstream infections.

Option B: The child-Pugh score is used to assess the severity of cirrhosis. 

Option D: Maddrey's Discriminant Function (MDF) score suggests which patients with alcoholic hepatitis may have a poor prognosis and benefit from steroid administration.

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who was a welder for the past 10 years presents with a dry cough, easy fatiguability, weight loss, and dyspnea progressing over the past 1 year. On examination, fine end-inspiratory crackles were heard over the bilateral infra-axillary regions. His HRCT finding is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The HRCT provided shows a characteristic crazy-paving pattern which is classical of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. 

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a lung disease involving the accumulation of surfactant within the alveoli as a result of decreased clearance. It may be congenital, secondary, or autoimmune.

Etiology:

  • Congenital
  • Secondary: due to lung infections, hematologic malignancies, and inhalation of mineral dust such as silica, titanium oxide, aluminum, indium-tin-oxide, and insecticides.
  • Autoimmune: autoantibodies against GM-CSF

Patients may have features like a persistent dry cough (or with scant sputum production), progressive dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss, intermittent low-grade fever and/or night sweats, and pleuritic chest pain. Rarely, they may have cyanosis and hemoptysis. The physical examination will show fine end-inspiratory crackles. Clubbing and cyanosis may be present in a few cases.

Diagnosis is with bronchoscopic lavage and/or biopsy, along with imaging findings. Chest X-ray shows nonspecific findings with bilateral lung opacification. A batwing appearance may be seen.

The CT shows a characteristic ‘crazy-paving’ pattern. It refers to geographical areas of ground-glass opacification with thickened inter-and intralobular septa.

Treatment includes whole lung lavage and treatment of the underlying cause. GM-CSF replacement is considered if an underlying autoimmune etiology is suspected.

Other causes causing similar crazy-paving appearance:

  • Lipoid pneumonia
  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia
  • Silicosis,
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: Biological transmission by an infectious agent that stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next is known as _________
questions.solution:
Biological transmission by an infectious agent which stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next is known as transstadial transmission.

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: What is the relation between intra-alveolar pressure and atmospheric pressure when lung volume is equal to the functional residual capacity?
questions.solution:
At functional residual capacity (FRC), the pressure of air in the alveoli equals atmospheric pressure.

When the volume of air present in the lungs is FRC, the tendency of the lung to collapse inwards is balanced by the tendency of the chest wall to spring outwards. The pressure inside the airways is equal to the atmospheric pressure. Hence, there is no net movement of air during this stage.

At volumes greater than the FRC, the collapsing force of the lung is greater than the expanding force of the chest wall — the entire system wants to collapse. The airway pressure is greater than the atmospheric pressure. Thus, the air flows out of the lungs, along the pressure gradient.

At volumes lesser than the FRC, the expanding force of the chest wall is greater than the collapsing force of the lung — the entire system wants to expand. The airway pressure is less than the atmospheric pressure. Thus, the air flows into the lungs, along the pressure gradient.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.6 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: For an acid with a single pKa, which of the following is true when pH is lower than pKa?

choices.text: More molecules are in the associated state
More molecules are in the dissociated state
State of molecules can’t be determined

questions.solution:
At pH lower than the pKa, more acid molecules are protonated/associated than deprotonated/dissociated.

pKa refers to the pH at which half of an acid is associated and half is dissociated. At pH lower than the pKa, more protons are available, and hence, more than half of the acid molecules are protonated/associated.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of poor growth, weakness, abnormal gait, and bowing of the legs. He was diagnosed with vitamin D deficiency rickets. Which of the following is increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The level of serum alkaline phosphatase is increased in this child with vitamin D deficiency rickets.

Nutritional rickets occur due to a deficiency of vitamin D. This leads to low calcium levels in the blood. To raise the serum calcium, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone rises. The parathyroid hormone tries to raise the calcium levels by :

  • Reabsorbing calcium in the kidneys and secreting phosphate in exchange leads to low phosphate levels
  • Increasing bone resorption

Lab findings:

  • Serum calcium- decreased
  • Serum phosphorus- decreased
  • Creatinine- normal
  • Alkaline phosphatase- increased
  • Urinary excretion of calcium- decreased

Related Pearl: Important Clinical Features of Rickets

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: Which of the following directly triggers the area postrema?
questions.solution:
The area postrema is also known as the chemoreceptor trigger zone and initiates vomiting in response to circulating chemical agents such as intravenously administered drugs. It is a V shaped band of tissue on the lateral walls of the fourth ventricle and has chemoreceptor cells with 5-HT3 and D2 receptors. Since it is situated outside of the blood brain barrier, its receptors can be activated by blood borne emetic agents and initiate vomiting.

Other options:

  • Irritation of the gastric mucosa may result in stimulation of the area postrema through the vagus nerve, but not directly.
  • In motion sickness, the signals are transmitted to the cerebellum from the labyrinth of the inner ear and end up in the brainstem vomiting centre.
  • Emotional stimuli induce vomiting through higher brain centres that stimulate the brainstem vomiting centre.

questions.text: CRH responsiveness and residual ACTH suppression by high-dose dexamethasone are seen in hypercortisolism due to:
questions.solution:
CRH responsiveness is seen only in hypercortisolism which is due to a pituitary cause.

Physiologically, CRH released from the hypothalamus has a stimulatory effect on the pituitary corticotropic cells, thus producing ACTH.

Hypercortisolism may be endogenous or iatrogenic.

  • Iatrogenic hypercortisolism is not affected by dynamic testing
  • Endogenous hypercortisolism may be ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent

ACTH-dependent Cushing’s syndrome can be further classified by dynamic testing:

Pituitary cause:

  • CRH test – Positive. ACTH increase > 40% at 15–30 min + cortisol increase >20% at 45–60 min after CRH 100 μg IV
  • High-dose dexamethasone suppression test - Positive. Cortisol suppression >50% after q6h 2 mg dexamethasone administration for 2 days

Ectopic cause:

  • CRH test - Negative
  • High-dose dexamethasone suppression test - Negative

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male underwent tooth extraction for caries tooth. 3 days later he presents with a fever and swelling on the right side of his neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. He also complains of difficulty in moving his jaw. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is found to be displaced medially. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, would be parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal abscess presents with:

  • Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid
  • Tonsils pushed medially
  • Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone)

Other options:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline.
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • Vincent’s angina (trench mouth) is an acute necrotizing infection of the oral cavity and the oropharynx.

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space
