questions.text: A child presents with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to Vit C, B12 and folic acid, but responsive to uridine. What do you suspect?
questions.solution:
Orotic aciduria is a rare disorder in children, resulting from a block in the metabolism of orotic acid.

Other causes of megaloblastic anemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency: Acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia
  • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine)
  • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine)

Administration of uridine, which is converted to UMP, will bypass the metabolic block and provide the body with a source of pyrimidine.

questions.text: Classification used for the assessment of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction is:
questions.solution:
Milwaukee classification is used for the assessment of sphincter of Oddi dysfunction.

Sphincter of Oddi dyskinesia or dysfunction (SOD) is a clinical syndrome in which pain, biochemical abnormalities, and dilatation of the bile duct and/or pancreatic duct are attributed to abnormal functions of the sphincter of Oddi.

The true incidence of SOD is unknown. Females are more commonly affected than males.

Etiology:

SOD may result from stenosis of the sphincter or from dysmotility. Scarring or stenosis of the sphincter can result from passage of stones, pancreatitis, or prior endoscopic sphincterotomies.

Milwaukee classification of sphincter of Oddi (SOD) dysfunction:

Biliary type SOD:

  • Type I:
    • Typical biliary type pain
    • Liver enzymes (aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT), or alkaline phosphatase (ALP)) >2 times normal limit documented on at least 2 occasions during episodes of pain
    • Dilated common bile duct (CBD) >12 mm in diameter
    • Prolonged biliary drainage time (>45 min)
  • Type II:
    • Biliary type pain, and
    • One or two of the above criteria
  • Type III:
    • Biliary type pain only

Pancreatic type SOD:

  • Type I:
    • Pancreatic type pain
    • Amylase and/or lipase >2 times upper normal limit on at least 2 occasions during episodes of pain
    • Dilated pancreatic duct (head >6 mm, body >5 mm)
    • Prolonged pancreatic drainage time (>9 min)
  • Type II:
    • Pancreatic type pain, and
    • One or two of the above criteria
  • Type III:
    • Pancreatic type pain only

Note:

Cystic tumours of the pancreas are classified according to the Klöppel’s classification system.

Choledocal cysts are classified according to the Todani classification system.

This is a recent NEET question. Classifications used for particular diseases are frequently being asked in almost all the examinations, especially in NEET, making them high-yield.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room after she lost consciousness briefly during a speech. An ECG was taken immediately. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows a constant PR interval in each successive cycle followed by a dropped QRS (P wave fails to produce a QRS complex). This pattern is suggestive of Mobitz type II block.

Mobitz type II block is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses.  

The dropped QRS is marked in the image below:

Note: Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction and AV block( Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.solution:

questions.text: According to DSM-5, which of the following is not a type of presentation of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder?
questions.solution:
According to the DSM-V, attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is diagnosed with one of three specifiers – predominantly inattentive, predominantly hyperactive/impulsive, or combined presentation with features of both.

For a diagnosis of ADHD, the following criteria have to be satisfied:

  • 6 out of 9 symptoms of inattention and/or hyperactivity with impulsivity have to be present for at least 6 months.
  • Symptoms should have started before the age of 12 years.
  • Symptoms must be present at least in two settings, such as home, school, work, etc.
  • Symptoms must have a negative impact on social and academic/occupational functioning.
  • Symptoms don’t occur exclusively during the course of a psychotic disorder and aren’t explained by any other mental disorder.

Note: For adults and adolescents aged 17 or older, 5 out of 9 symptoms are adequate for diagnosis.

questions.text: According to ACOG guidelines, which of the following is the preferred mode of delivery in a hemodynamically stable woman with peripartum cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
The ACOG recommends vaginal delivery with slowly induced epidural analgesia for hemodynamically stable women with peripartum cardiomyopathy. Cesarean section under spinal-epidural/general anesthesia is done in women who are hemodynamically unstable or when there are other obstetric indications.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy is defined as systolic left ventricular failure (LVEF < 45%) without a determinable cause, presenting between the last month of gestation and five months postpartum in a woman without known cardiovascular disease.

 

Epidural analgesia is preferred because the cardiac output is relatively fixed and slow induction of epidural analgesia minimizes hypotension, reduces preload, and decreases cardiac output.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for puncture aspiration injection re-aspiration (PAIR) of hydatid cyst?
questions.solution:
Infected cyst is an indication for puncture aspiration injection reaspiration (PAIR) of hydatid cyst.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: Which of the following ion is co-transported with dipeptides and tripeptides into the enterocytes by peptide transporter 1?
questions.solution:
Hydrogen ion/proton is co-transported with dipeptides/tripeptides into the enterocytes by peptide transporter 1. Within the enterocytes, the peptides undergo hydrolysis and amino acids are released.

Note: Amino acids are co-transported into the enterocytes along with sodium ions.

questions.text: A point mutation that changes an amino-acid codon to a stop codon is:
questions.solution:
A point mutation that changes an amino-acid codon to a stop codon is a non-sense mutation. eg. beta-thalassemia.

Frame-shift mutation- addition or loss of DNA base changes a gene's reading frame. eg. Duchenes muscular dystrophy.

Mis-sense mutation-  It may alter the code in a triplet of bases and lead to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. eg. Sickle cell anaemia.

Silent mutation- The altered codon codes for the same amino acid, hence there is no phenotypic change.

questions.text: What is the function of the proteasome?
questions.solution:
The proteasome takes part in protein degradation. 

The proteasome is a cylindrical structure in the cytosol that degrades polyubiquitinated proteins. It has a central core with proteolytic enzymes. Proteins that are tagged by ubiquitin to be degraded enter the core through regulatory rings on either side of the cylinder.

Clinical relevance: It plays an important role in antigen presentation to T lymphocytes as it degrades viruses and other molecules to small peptides.

questions.text: A person involved in a road traffic accident has a peculiar posture with clenched hands and flexed upper limbs. The lower limbs are extended with toes pointing inwards. Which of the following is associated with this posture?
questions.solution:
The described posture is seen in decorticate rigidity caused by lesions rostral to the midbrain. There is flexion of the upper limbs at the elbow and extension of the lower limbs. Flexion is due to rubrospinal excitation of the muscles of the upper extremities.

Other options:

Option B: In decerebrate rigidity, the lesion involves motor tracts caudal to the midbrain and involves the rubrospinal tract. Hence, all four limbs are extended in this condition.

Note: Posturing in decerebrate rigidity becomes exaggerated if the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is damaged and this is called decerebellate rigidity.

Option C: Uncal herniation is associated with decerebrate posturing.

questions.text: Individuals who had subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease are known as:
questions.solution:
Healthy carriers are those who had a subclinical infection and developed carrier state without suffering from overt disease. However, they still shed the disease agent.

Examples: Poliomyelitis, cholera, meningococcal meningitis, salmonellosis, and diphtheria.

All individuals with a subclinical infection are not considered as carriers. Only those, who disseminate or shed the disease agent are considered as carriers. For example, in polio, the infection may be subclinical, and the person may shed the virus, thus acting as a healthy carrier. In contrast, a patient with tuberculosis may have a subclinical infection but doesn't disseminate the tubercle bacilli. In such case, the individual with subclinical tuberculosis infection is not a carrier.

Other options:

Paradoxical carriers are carriers who acquired the pathogen from another carrier. Example: A carrier with subclinical polio infection, who acquired the pathogen from another household member, who is also a carrier for polio virus.

Incubatory carriers are those who shed infectious agents during the incubation period of the disease. Which means, these carriers transmit the disease before the onset of the illness. Examples: measles, mumps, polio, pertussis, influenza, diphtheria and hepatitis B.

Convalescent carriers are those who continue to shed the disease agent during the period of convalescence. This may occur in cases where the clinical recovery does not coincide with the bacteriological recovery, and the individual may continue to shed the disease agent. Examples: Typhoid fever, dysentery (bacillary and amoebic), cholera, diphtheria and whooping cough.

questions.text: What is the most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus?
questions.solution:
The most common neurological manifestation seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is cognitive impairment.

It can manifest as impaired memory and reasoning. Other common neurological manifestations in SLE are psychosis, depression, and seizures.

The most common manifestations of different systems involved in SLE are:

  • Musculoskeletal- arthritis and arthralgia
  • Skin- photosensitivity
  • Kidneys- proteinuria
  • Neurologic- cognitive impairment
  • Cardiac- pericarditis
  • Pulmonary- pleuritis
  • Hematologic- anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
The bradycardia seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by baroreceptor activation in response to a raised arterial blood pressure.

The Cushing reflex is a triad of raised arterial blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respiration caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Raised ICP compromises blood flow to the brain and activates the rostral ventrolateral medulla with an increase in arterial blood pressure. The increased arterial pressure maintains cerebral perfusion and activates the baroreceptor reflex that causes bradycardia.

The irregular respiration seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by inadequate blood flow and increased pressure on the brainstem.

Bainbridge reflex: It refers to the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and pulmonary circulation.

J reflex: C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. 

Bezold Jarisch reflex (Coronary chemoreflex): Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

questions.text: The most common type of invasive breast cancers are:
questions.solution:
ER-positive, HER- negative is the most common form of invasive breast cancer.

ER-positive cancers are termed “luminal,” as these cancers most closely resemble normal breast luminal cells in their mRNA expression pattern.

HER2-positive is the second most common molecular subtype of invasive breast cancer.

questions.text: Identify the function of the instrument shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is a Hegar’s double ended dilator that is used to dilate the cervix in procedures such as dilatation and curettage.

Other options:

Metal catheter used to drain urine is shown below.

Simpson's uterine sound used to measure uterine cavity and cervical length.

Rubin's cannula used in hysterosalpingography.

questions.solution:
Hyaline cartilage is made up of type II collagen.

Type I collagen (fibrocartilage), Type II collagen (hyaline and elastic).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the properties of MHC proteins?

choices.text: MHC Class III- Presents extracellular antigens
MHC Class II - Presents intracellular antigens
MHC Class II - Expressed on antigen presenting cells
MHC Class I - Does not present antigens

questions.solution:
MHC proteins:

  • MHC Class I- Presents intracellular antigens, expressed by all the nucleated cells
  • MHC Class II- Presents extracellular antigens, expressed by antigen presenting cells
  • MHC Class III- include some complement components and TNF-alpha and Lymphotoxin-alpha, do not function in antigen presentation.

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensives can cause renal stones?
questions.solution:
Bumetanide is a urolithogenic antihypertensive.

Urolithogenic drugs are

  • Antihypertensive:
    • Furosemide, bumetanide (loop diuretics)
    • Triamterene (potassium-sparing diuretic)
  • Decongestant: Ephedrine
  • Expectorant: Guaifenesin
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: acetazolamide, topiramate, and zonisamide
  • Antiretroviral agents:
    • Indinavir (highest incidence)
    • Iopinavir-ritonavir
    • Ritonavir-boosted atazanavir
    • Nelfinavir
    • Amprenavir

questions.text: Which of the following glycolytic enzymes generates ATP?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate kinase and phosphoglycerate kinase are the glycolytic enzymes that catalyze substrate-level phosphorylation and generate ATP. Each enzyme generates 2 molecules of ATP per molecule of glucose.

Other options:

Hexokinase and phosphofructokinase consume one molecule of ATP per molecule of glucose.

Thus, the net gain of ATP is 4 – 2 = 2.

Note:

2 molecules of NADH are also generated during glycolysis and yield 5 ATP molecules after being oxidized in the electron transport chain. This process takes place only in aerobic glycolysis.

Hence, in aerobic glycolysis, 7 ATP molecules are generated ultimately, whereas in anaerobic glycolysis, only 2 ATP molecules are generated.

 

Other than pyruvate and phosphoglycerate kinase in glycolysis, succinate thiokinase also catalyzes substrate-level phosphorylation in the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: All of the following muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except?
questions.solution:
Palatoglossus is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes (hence innervated by the hypoglossal nerve), except palatoglossus, which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vago-accessory nerve.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve.
  • All the muscles of pharynx except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Tracheal tug sign is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Tracheal tug sign, also known as Oliver’s sign, is seen in arch of aorta aneurysm.

It is elicited by gently grasping the cricoid cartilage and applying upward pressure while the patient stands with their chin extended upward. Due to the anatomical position of the arch, which overrides the left main bronchus, a tug on the trachea is felt if an aneurysm is present. Therefore, it is also called as the tracheal tug sign.

questions.text: True statement about coronary steal phenomenon:

choices.text: Caused by isoflurane induced coronary vasoconstriction
Occurs in the presence of hypotension

questions.solution:
Coronary steal phenomenon occurs in the presence of hypotension.

Coronary steal phenomenon-redistribution of coronary blood flow away from ischemic myocardium due to coronary vasodilation produced by isoflurane when there is hypotension. This leads to higher flows in the normal zone and lower flows in the ischemic zone.

Coronary steal can be avoided if the coronary perfusion pressure is maintained.

questions.text: Identify the sign of intrauterine fetal death shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows Spalding sign with irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another. It usually appears 7 days after death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Which of the following derivatives of Ricinus communis plant is not toxic?
questions.solution:
Oil derived from the seeds of Ricinus plant is not toxic.

Ricinus communism is the castor plant. The entire plant is poisonous.

The seeds are poisonous containing the toxin, ricin. The unbroken seeds are non poisonous. Toxin is released only if the seeds are crushed.

When the oil is extracted from the seeds, the toxin ricin remains in the seed pulp and does not enter the oil.

Castor oil is used as a purgative.

questions.text: Hypercalcemia in a patient with sarcoidosis is due to:

choices.text: Production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D by the granuloma

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia and/or hypercalciuria occur in 10% of patients with sarcoidosis. The mechanism of abnormal calcium metabolism is due to the increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy-vitamin D by the granuloma itself. This results in increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia with a suppressed PTH level. Increased Vitamin D from diet or sunlight exposure may exacerbate this problem.

Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. These granulomas express 1-alpha hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium which results in hypercalcemia.

The lungs are most commonly affected in sarcoidosis, and the patients commonly present with cough and dyspnea. The involvement of the right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar lymph nodes leads to a characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement known as the Garland triad, 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: An Rh-negative primigravida has a second-trimester abortion. An indirect Coombs test done on the maternal serum is negative. According to ACOG guidelines, which of the following is to be done to prevent Rh isoimmunization?

choices.text: Repeat indirect Coombs test after 2 weeks
No treatment needed as patient is unsensitized
Administer 300 mcg of anti-Rh antibody within 72 hours
Administer 50 mcg of anti-Rh antibody within 72 hours

questions.solution:
The ACOG recommends the administration of 300 μg of anti-Rh antibody within 72 hours of all second and third-trimester abortions in unsensitized Rh-negative females.

This dose can also be administered in other events with the risk of fetomaternal hemorrhages such as abdominal trauma, obstetric hemorrhage, external cephalic version, as well as invasive procedures such as cordocentesis or amniocentesis and intrauterine fetal death.

The recommended dose for first-trimester abortions is 50 μg. This also applies to molar pregnancies, ectopic pregnancies, and invasive procedures such as chorionic villus sampling.

For Rh-negative women with an ongoing pregnancy, an indirect Coombs test is done at 28 weeks of gestation. If negative, it means that the mother is unsensitized and 300 μg of anti-Rh antibody is administered.

After delivery, Rh typing of the newborn is done. If the newborn is found to be Rh positive, another 300 μg dose of anti-Rh antibody is administered to the mother within 72 hours.

Related Pearl: Indications of Amniotic Fluid Color

Amniotic fluid colour Inference
Colourless Early pregnancy
Straw yellow  Term pregnancy (exfoliated lanugo, epidermal cells from fetal skin)
Meconium stained (green) Fetal distress (other than breech / transverse)
Golden  Rh incompatibility (excessive hemolysis of fetal RBC, excess bilirubin)
Greenish yellow (saffron) Post maturity
Dark red Concealed accidental hemorrhage (contamination of blood)
Dark brown (tobacco juice) Intrauterine death (presence of old HbA)

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman who is a known case of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) presents with severe abdominal pain, hypotension, and decreased level of consciousness. On further examination, colonic artery rupture was discovered. This occurs due to the defects in which type of collagen in EDS?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a typical case of vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) that occurs due to defects in type III collagen.

EDS is a connective tissue disorder occuring due to genetic defects involved in collagen synthesis and action. It is characterized by hyperextensibility of skin, hypermobile joints, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

The vascular variant of EDS has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. It was previously known as type IV EDS. It results from defects in type III collagen and occurs due to a mutation in the COL3A1 gene. Unlike other types of EDS, hyperextensibility of skin is absent in the vascular type of EDS. The skin is thin and translucent with visible veins. Other features of vascular EDS include arterial rupture, uterine rupture, bruising, and small joint hyperextensibility.

The collagen defects in other variants of EDS are:

  • Arthrochalasia and dermatosparaxis EDS: Defective conversion of type I procollagen to collagen
  • Classical EDS: Mutation in the gene encoding type V collagen

Note: The classification of EDS in the pearl is based on clinical subtypes of EDS and not based on the type of collagen involved in the disease. The numbers in brackets indicate the Roman numbers used by the previous classification (not the type of collagen involved).

questions.text: An obstructive lesion at which of the following levels will cause only expiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi (D) will cause expiratory stridor.

Other options:

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: The chromosomal abnormality associated in a neonate with prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet is most probably _________
questions.solution:
Prominent occiput, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet are all features of Edwards syndrome, i.e., Trisomy 18.

Trisomy 18 - Edwards syndrome:

  • Low birth weight
  • Closed fists with index finger overlapping the 3rd digit and the 5th digit overlapping the 4th
  • Narrow hips with limited abduction
  • Short sternum
  • Rocker-bottom feet
  • Microcephaly
  • Prominent occiput
  • Micrognathia
  • Cardiac and renal malformations
  • Intellectual disability

questions.text: Classified according to the vascular anatomy of the muscle, what type of muscle is gastrocnemius?
questions.solution:
Gastrocnemius is a type I muscle, with a single vascular pedicle supplying the muscle belly supplied by the sural artery.

The gross vascular anatomy of muscles has been classified into five types according to the number and relative dominance of vascular pedicles that enter the muscle. This classification has important surgical relevance in determining which muscles will survive, and therefore be useful for pedicled or free tissue transfer procedures in plastic and reconstructive surgery.

Type Blood supply Examples
Type I A single vascular pedicle supplying the muscle belly Tensor fasciae latae, Gastrocnemius
Type II A single dominant vascular pedicle and several minor pedicles Gracilis
Type III Two separate dominant pedicles, from different source arteries. Rectus abdominis, Gluteus maximus
Type IV Multiple small pedicles that, are not capable of supporting the muscle individually Sartorius and Tibialis anterior
Type V One dominant vascular pedicle and multiple secondary segmental pedicles Latissimus Dorsi

questions.text: In the context of changes during pregnancy, what is meant by lightening?

choices.text: Perception of foetal movements by mother
Foetal engagement with relief of pressure
Pigmentation over the forehead and cheeks

questions.solution:
Engagement of the fetal presenting part produces a sense of relief from abdominal pressure, especially in primigravida around 38 weeks of gestation. This is called lightening.

Other options:

  • Perception of active fetal movements by the mother is called quickening. It is felt at around 18 weeks of gestation in primigravida and about two weeks earlier in multigravida.
  • Pigmentation over the forehead and cheeks is called chloasma and it appears at about the 24th week of gestation.
  • Abdominal striae appear in the second trimester and appear white or pink. A linear dark pigmented line called the linea nigra also develops in the second trimester and extends from the symphysis pubis to the xiphoid cartilage.
